characters: JANET TUCKER SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND
GET BACK IN GET BACK IN GET-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie leads Boy and Girl.  She reaches the back door. Boards cover the door’s glass inset. Boy and Girl hold hands. Girl’s knuckles go white. Boy squeezes back. On the floor by the door: A bird cage. Inside: A little, fat budgie. Malorie bends down, cups her hands... And transfers the bird to a shoebox. It coos at her as she covers the box and hefts it. Malorie then picks up her blindfold. Before donning it, she looks around. Inside, all is quiet and still. A land-line phone sits on the coffee table. Nothing else around it. As if it were a holy relic. Malorie secures her blindfold. Reaches out and grips the door handle. Takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Twenty, thirty-one, fifty-four. Twenty, thirty-one, fifty-four. (then) Here we go. With trembling hand, she opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Malorie’s face. Advancing into the back yard. Whispering under her breath. TIGHT on Boy and Girl. They form a train behind her. Girl crooks her head left and right. In the distance, a generator thrums. Glimpses of: yellowed grass. Overcast sky. It’s cold. Malorie steps carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Eighteen, nineteen... twenty.  Her hand reaches out to her right... And finds a fence post. She pivots and marches another direction. Farther away from the house. Slightly downhill. Boy and Girl take note of this shift.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (whispered) Left.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (whispered) Okay. The three march on.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Twenty-nine, thirty, thirty-one. Malorie raises her hand... And touches a tree branch. She lets out a breath of relief. And she changes direction once more. Boy and Girl adapt. The sound of the river creeps in. Malorie quietly counts her steps. Then: A sound. Rustling. The sigh of foliage. Boy’s ear perks. He pauses. It stops the train. Boy and Girl turn their heads the same direction. Beat. Listening. Then, another rustle. Back the way they came. The budgie inside the shoebox CHIRPS. Its wings scrape against the box lid.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (sotto) Malorie.  Malorie tenses and starts them moving. Faster now.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Forty-nine, fifty, fifty-one, fifty- two, fifty three... fifty-four. The sound of the river is close. Malorie reaches out and down... But her fingers grasp air. No landmark here. Malorie sweeps her arm around. Still nothing. Somewhere off to the right: Leaves rustle. Closer. The budgie CHIRPS in distress. Girl tugs at Malorie’s arm. Malorie starts to hyperventilate. She steps forward. Groping.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Fifty-five. Rustle.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sotto) Pifty-six--

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Getting closer-- Her fingers stretch-- And touch the end of a ROWBOAT. Malorie puts a foot in the boat and lifts Girl inside. Then Boy. And follows them in. The three push off, into the river’s flow. As Malorie begins to row. A branch CRACKS nearby. The oar dips into the water.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Malorie’s hand dips into soapy bath water. We’re now in:  INT. MALORIE’S BATHROOM - DAY Malorie drains her tub after a bath. She’s wrapped a towe around her head, partly dressed in bra and panties, so it clear she is six months pregnant. This is five years earlier. She looks radiant, bright-eye and when she unwraps the towel, LONG HAIR flows out. Malorie runs a hand over her baby bump. Questioning. All by herself, naked both physically and emotionally, sh stares at her belly as if it were concerning news. INT. MALORIE’S LIVING ROOM - DAY A painting of a river hangs over a cheap fireplace. Nearb TV plays a fashion reality program. Malorie sits on the floor with her back against a faded s She’s dressed comfortably now, but made up.

dialogues.speaker: FASHION HOST ON TV, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And now it’s time to transform her from ‘hot mess’ to ‘princess.’ Before Malorie: a baby shower gift in pretty wrapping pap Around it lay the paper remains of previously opened gift She tears into the wrapping. This baby shower gift is a wipe warmer. And a card. WRITTEN INSIDE: “Better find a husband soon! xo Alison” Malorie makes a noise with her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Alison, you bitch. She clucks her tongue and logs the gift on a notepad. Malorie sits up as someone enters her front door. JESSICA, Malorie’s sister. A skinnier, fiercer version of Malorie. Carrying groceries like they’re 500 pounds.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Holy fuck, the store was packed. This thing is serious.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn to the news.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What channel? Jessica carries the bags to the kitchen. Over her shoulde

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Any of them. SWITCHING CHANNELS, the TV lands on footage of two ambula at a park at night, loading bodies on stretchers.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And in Tula, a city south of Moscow, last reports estimated a death toll of twenty-one thousand. It’s yet to be determined if this is from an airborne pathogen, but some liken the symptoms to a sudden onset of psychotic behavior. Malorie gets up and follows Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica unloads the bags. Malorie loiters nearby.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN OFFICIAL ON TV, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: --not that we know of, but somehow it’s spreading at an alarming rate, which is why we are being careful--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s in Russia.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Try telling that to the soccer moms fighting over the bottled water. I don't want you going out there until people remember to calm the fuck down. Okay? Is Dad texting you survivalist bullshit? Jessica uncaps a beer bottle with her shirt, takes a swig

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I was in the bath. I have that OB appointment, remember?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Shit! Right. I can drive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should postpone. Jessica faces Malorie, who won’t make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Hey. We talked about this. It’1l be fine. You’re having this baby.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: I was an accident, too. Ask mom. Jessica goes back to stowing the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: But Dad never bailed on Mom.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter. Moms are moms. Malorie nods. Trying to buy into it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How goes the Great Unwrapping?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It goes. I don’t know what half this stuff does. Alison got me something.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Seriously? What?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (grin forming) A wipe warmer.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Perfect. You’1ll think of her every time you wipe the kid’s ass. C’mon, let’s get you to the doctor. Jessica grabs her car keys and her purse from the counter

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: --but the CDC has not found any evidence of a contagion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica passes Malorie, on march for the front door, but Malorie lingers a moment, captivated by something on TV. ON SCREEN: low-quality dashboard camera footage of civili fleeing past the car in a downtown district. One of the people running by wears a HOSPITAL GOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie sits on an exam table, wearing a HOSPITAL GOWN. DR. SUE LAPHAM (40s, cheery) is dressed in a white coat o her street clothes, and she gestures with her clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAPHAM
dialogues.text: Thanks for meeting here, by the way. Another patient of mine is about to pop. How have you been feeling? Sleeping any better?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Sleep is still rough. No one told me how hard it would be to get comfortable in this shape.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAPHAM
dialogues.text: You know my method? Couch cushions on the bed. Here and here, so your belly fits between them.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I’1l try that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAPHAM
dialogues.text: You're due in twelve weeks, so let's try some natural remedies for the insomnia before I prescribe anything. (casually) You have a name picked?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Not yet. Something about it... It hasn't really clicked with me. You know? The idea. Motherhood.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAPHAM
dialogues.text: That’s normal. It will pass. Malorie smiles sadly and nods. While holding that smile:  10.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What if it doesn’t? Dr. Lapham reads from her clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAPHAM
dialogues.text: Everything will change after the baby’s born. Now, let’s talk about the next trimester. Expect more weight gain, but if it gets more than forty pounds over where you were before, call me. CREEPING IN on Malorie as she listens to the doctor, and all plays out on her face: A silent war against encroachi anxiety. She looks away. Takes a breath as Lapham continu DR. LAPHAM (0.S.) (CONT’D) Heartburn will be more common. You might also deal with hemorrhoids, discharge, bleeding, and varicose veins, that’s all natural. Be aware of Braxton Hicks contractions at odd hours, like tremors before a real quake... The doctor's voice grows more and more distant as Malorie struggles to keep it all together. And then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie vomits into the toilet bowl. She cleans herself up at the sink and stares at herself i the mirror. Her own bloodshot eyes stare back. Malorie washes her face. Then goes to the towels to dry h face and hands. Nearby: A basket of reading material. Magazines. Pamphlet Flyers about parenthood, childbirth. Malorie notices one. Picks it up. The headline: “YOU HAVE A CHOICE. // Give your child to a good home!” An informational flyer on adoption. Malorie considers something. Then puts the flyer in her purse.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cacophony of noise. Malorie navigates a hallway, leaving Lapham’s office. A p of PARAMEDICS rush by the other way, wheeling a MAN with leg injury on a gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commotion is louder here. Other PATIENTS waiting for urgent care watch in horror at the scene playing out in t corner of the room-- A WOMAN in a pricey jogging suit and glossy fingernails shrills at two NURSES trying to close in on her-- As she SCREAMS non-words she digs her fingernails into he right cheek and begins to tear into her flesh-- With her other hand she starts with the thin skin around eyelid and pulls-- And the NURSES go for her and blood gets everywhere and Malorie hurries out the door amid the AD LIB SHOUTS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie gets to Jessica’s car in visitor parking. Shaking Jessica waits in the driver's seat, texting on her phone. INT. JESSICA’S CAR Jessica doesn’t look up from her phone as Malorie gets in

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: How'd it go? Still having a baby?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s happening now. This gets her attention.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: The baby?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No, the-- whatever it is in Russia. The thing that makes you go crazy? I think it’s here.  12.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Doctor Lapham is crazy?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Can we get going please?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Okay, number one, you gotta calm down for me. And B-- Outside, an ambulance drives up, lights and sirens going, screeches to a halt at the door. The back of the ambulanc rocks violently from some struggle playing out inside. Jessica notices, tosses her phone in her purse, throws it back, and starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica’s car tears out just as two squad cars pull in. INT. JESSICA’S CAR - DAY Malorie holds her phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Who are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: They'll be fine. Takes an act of congress to get them out of their house more than once a week. Malorie listens with the phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Voicemail. (to Jess) It went to voicemail. Jessica lets out a stiff breath, then changes lanes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: We'll swing by. But I’m calling it now: They're both fine. At the next red light, they pull up alongside another car A YOUNG MAN drives with his pretty GIRLFRIEND.  13. He nods at Malorie. Malorie nods back. They’re strangers, just checking in with each other. It’s okay. Then: A loud but distant CRACK. And a RUMBLE. Malorie loo around -- it’s behind her. Four blocks back and one or two over: A FIRECLOUD. Smoke rising like black cellophane.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn. Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like this. Jess, can we just go? Maybe we just drive. In the adjacent car, Young Man with his panicked Girlfrie does that: he looks at cross traffic, and runs the red li Other traffic screeches and veers, HONKING.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jess-—

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: I’m not doing anything stupid. You're pregnant. The light turns green a moment later. Jessica mashes the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upper middle class. Not mansions, but trying. Jessica’s car navigates the streets amid sparse traffic. The clouds are the color of fresh bruises. Distant thunde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica and Malorie take the ride in silence. Tense. Malo fidgets nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Where is all the traffic?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Okay you need to cool it because you're starting to freak me out now, okay? And we can’t both be freaking out.  14.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Sorry. A phone RINGS. Malorie looks down at her phone in her lap

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Is it Dad?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s not my phone--

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: In back, in my purse-- It RINGS again. Malorie reaches back, into Jessica’s purs She opens the bag and digs for the phone as it RINGS-- Bent over, head down, Malorie finds the phone just as the call screen switches to MISSED CALL and-- JESSICA (0.S.) (CONT’D) OH MY GOD what was that, did you see that what was it? Malorie brings the phone up front, frowning--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: See what? Jessica’s body language and posture changes. Her muscles are rigid. Hands wringing the wheel. And her eyes flit constantly. Her voice cracks--

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Back there I mean what I saw-- Malorie presses the RETURN CALL on the phone and puts it her ear while talking to Jessica--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Okay, calm down, hey--

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: What I saw it was, it was-- Malorie looks back as she listens to RING on the other en the line-- MALORIE’S POV: A slight hill in the road prevents her from seeing anythi past the SUV half a block back, but it swerves violently-  15.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t care now I don’t care anymore-- And now the phone is RINGING in Malorie’s ear and a seat alarm is BEEPING and somewhere a truck’s HORN is honking engine REVS as Jessica picks up speed all the while looki right at Malorie--

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're all going to die.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Jess, what-- Malorie sees it a fraction before it happens: Jessica has steered into oncoming traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pickup truck SMASHES into the left front bumper-- BOTH VEHICLES crumple at the hood in an eruption of plast metal, glass, and shredded rubber-- Airbags deploy like white mushroom clouds-- Jessica’s car spins away, momentum carrying it back to th curb as the pickup limps into a parked car-- And then after the screech and crunch and terror: Stillness. The car’s engine has died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie’s airbag deflates, revealing a breathless Malorie dusted in white safety powder, trying to get her bearings She instinctively puts her hands to her belly. Her seatbelt and the airbag saved them. A hiss of air deflating nearby draws her attention to: Jessica. Pushing her airbag out of the way. Only one arm working for her. The other one is bleeding profusely. A c over her forehead has bathed her face in blood.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Oh my god... Jess...  16. Jessica looks at her with the eyes of a feral creature. She turns the ignition to start the car again. Her mouth moves as if she’s speaking, but it’s soft as a prayer. Malorie is in pure shock, and terrified by her sister. She unbuckles the seatbelt and opens her car door to esca And Jessica grapples Malorie’s wrist, croaking a warning:

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: You stay in. Malorie struggles to break free--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Let go, Jess, let go-- And wrenches away from her and out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie stumbles away to the sidewalk and looks back at Jessica in shock.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?!

dialogues.speaker: GET BACK IN GET BACK IN GET-
dialogues.text: And the SUV from down the block COLLIDES with the back of car, WIPING Jessica and the vehicle out of frame like a runaway locomotive. Malorie flinches in surprise. But it doesn’t stop. Another CAR accelerates from down th street, veering toward Malorie like a missile. Malorie turns and starts to run. Her inner ear still rings from the crash. She can’t move at six months pregnant. For six utterly agonizing seconds, she moves for a tree w the car barrels down behind her, popping the curb at fift miles per hour, the driver LAUGHING at the wheel-- Malorie ducks behind the tree trunk JUST AS the car colli with it behind her--  17. The front end WRAPPING around the trunk on either side of in a shuddering impact-- And the tree rains down a few hundred leaves on her in a terrible aftershock to the one-note cry of the stuck HORN Malorie takes her hands down from her head, still holding breath. The horn blares, mingling with the ringing in her ear. Shell-shocked, she gets up and starts walking. Anywhere. Away from the wreckage both behind her and on t street, where her sister’s body is surely mangled inside. Her hands shake involuntarily. She can’t quite breathe. FOLLOWING with Malorie, that war with terror and anxiety playing out on her face again. A hand reaches for her, out of frame, touching her should Malorie SCREAMS-- It’s a tall, sturdy-looking MAN who shows her his hands i gesture of peace. His name is TOM (late 30s, blue-collar countenance, gentle eyes).

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. It’s okay. (beat) But we need to get inside.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: My sister--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Right now. He holds out his hand. Malorie takes it. And they start to run. AHEAD: Another pack of people caught outside at the momen also start to run, searching for a destination. A surly MAN with a pedometer is among them. This Man is DONALD (mid-40s, former hipster). Donald is the perpetual critic who needs to be the smartest man in the room.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Don’t look back! Just keep facing this way! Listen to me!  18. An Hispanic woman (LUCY, 20s, athletic clothes) crosses t street ahead of Donald on a similar mission to find shelt Then we see where she’s going-- Three houses ahead, a well-dressed, middle-aged WOMAN (LY gestures at them from her driveway.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Hurry! It’s not safe out here! Lucy is the first to her front door, where she meets Lydi husband GREG (50s, worry lines on his face) in the thresh She steps in just as Donald gets there and tells Greg:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Pull the curtains. Now. Greg and Donald go inside-- Malorie moves as fast as she can at six months pregnant. focus is on Lydia. Lydia keeps stepping farther down the driveway as she ush people into her house, looking past Malorie, trying to sh over the din of the stuck horn. Then, Lydia’s body language changes. Her posture gets rigid. She trembles as if struck by sudd illness. Her eyes widen. And her voice stops making words, and instead begins utte a sound out of tune from the blaring horn. Lydia takes two steps and then runs directly into the str Just as a speeding CAR drives past and RAMS into Lydia, yanking her over the hood and roof-- The crowd witnesses it in silent shock. Greg appears at the door again. Sees his wife’s body. And goes as if to run to her. Donald grabs him and pulls him back, and soon more NEIGHB rush in for him to obscure his view of her-- But Malorie. She can feel that question in her brain. Tha primal curiosity. She starts to turn her head and look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nearly does when TOM puts a hand over that side of he face and firmly grips her arm--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No you’re not. Come on. He guides her for the house. From inside, Greg's voice ca heard, arguing. Tom and Malorie cross the threshold, into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house. The same one as in the opener. Tom closes the behind him. They’re the last ones in. Head count: eight or nine. Most of them catching their breath, pacing, two of them silently crying from the trau of witnessing two deaths up close. Malorie watches as: Donald pulls at the heavy curtains in the living room nea

dialogues.speaker: LUCY DONALD
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that-- They’re all going crazy! Greg can’t stop pacing. To no one in particular--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: And did you see it? He came out of nowhere and just ran her over? I mean what is wrong with the drivers out there I mean really? (then) I have to get his plates. Greg moves for the door and immediately Lucy, Tom, and tw other MEN hold him back.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s not safe right now. Let’s just-- give it a while. Malorie backs away from the door. Outside, the horn still blares. Accompanied by a scream, suddenly cut off. And then a distant GUNSHOT. Malorie stares at the door the whole time. Crying in shoc some part of her aware her sister is dead. Trembling.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Something was behind us.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Did you see it?  20.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course not. Donald steps in from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If she had, she would’ve lost her mind, like the others.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: My sister saw it. Another one of the group chimes in: FELIX (mid-20s, skinn leather jacket, a motorcycle helmet in one fist).

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: You're talking about the virus in Europe? Tom’s attention dances from Malorie back to Donald.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: That’s a bullshit story. It’s living things from who-knows-where-- CHERYL (50s, busybody with “traditional values”) interjec

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Like aliens? Lucy chimes in aggressively. She’s the type of woman you' guess has five older brothers.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh come on, aliens?--

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: They discounted that, no airspace has been invaded-- Another man wearing a fishing vest speaks up loudly, step on Donald’s information. This is JASON.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Give me a break now, really. A few people get into a car accident and now we’re making up monsters comin’ outta the woods. I don’t claim to know what’s going on in some other countries but I know not to fall for any of that conspiracy crap-- (pointing at Don) --and the rest o’you’1ll come around once the adrenaline stops flowing.  21.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD JASON
dialogues.text: (re: “that crap”) (salutes) Yeah thanks for that. Now I’m leaving. But Jason pauses, aware of the chaos and screams out fron He decides better of it and steps back.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘’1l take the back door, just to avoid that mess. The others watch Jason march off for the rear of the hous Somewhere beyond, a door slams shut a moment later.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Look, you can join Bold And Stupid out the back but I’m telling you this is very serious, so listen up. People online were saying how just witnessing one of those things out there is enough to snap your brain--

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: What things? More VOICES overlap again, everyone arguing different poi until Tom raises both hands up high and CLAPS.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey! Calm down. We can talk about this like adults, and we’re out of immediate danger. All right? We can figure this out. He says it with conviction, and in a moment gets the comm of the room. Malorie sees it happen, just like that-- the don’t listen to Donald like they do with Tom. She sees Do reacting to it, too. Quietly affronted by the turn of tid

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: My parents are about a mile from here, on Arbor. I need to get to them. I need to go. Greg is in denial, his voice cracking as he talks:

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I have to check on Lydia-- The group gets hyper again and then Tom holds up a finger placing himself protectively at the door.  22.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hold on. Let’s stay put until the chaos dies down. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Greg.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: This is your house?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Me and Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How many windows do you have on the back side of the house?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Windows? Uh. Quite a few.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: (re-asserting) Curtains?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Blinds-- why, what does this--

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You two: What are your names?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Felix.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let’s go close some blinds. Try not to look outside if you can help it. And you--

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Don, yeah. I already did the front side, so I’m just gonna stay here if you don’t mind. Tom leads Felix and Lucy away, toward the kitchen. The rest of the group remains standing or sitting on the bottom steps of the front stairs.  23. Donald looks up to the landing.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Greg? How many floors is this?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: A lot of windows.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Can you send your housekeeper up to close them all up?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Housekeeper?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: That girl Lucy, isn’t she--?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I don’t know her.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. I live two doors down, and we have heavy foliage blocking our house. For privacy?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: My husband and my son will be back from Lansing pretty soon. So if you want to relocate, I’m just saying. Outside, among the chaos: a distant sound. Inhuman. Otherworldly. No creature in wildlife sounds like it. The noise reverberates through the house.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It isn’t safe to go outside. At all.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: How long do you think we’1ll have to stay inside?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A couple of hours? Malorie’s attention returns to the door. Her posture rigi and tense. And her hand on her belly.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years later. Ivy has snaked over an orphaned tricycle. Rust cakes a car’s sideview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie steadies herself on the row boat. Girl turns her head toward Malorie.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You stopped rowing.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Just taking a break. Keep listening. No talking. Beat. But because she’s four years old:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (sotto) How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sigh) A few hours.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (sotto) What is it like?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) I don’t know. It’s a safe place. Protected with high walls. They say there’s even a courtyard, so you can walk around outside. Girl asks it like it’s Santa Claus:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Trees?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Trees. (hardening) Now if you refuse to keep quiet, tell me the steps again. Tell me the steps.  25.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Eighty-six, forty-four, thirty.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Boy. Landmarks.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Statue. Bridge. Car. Stone.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Good. Now quiet. Listen.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (beat, sotto) What’s a car? Malorie realizes: They don’t know. The children have never seen one. Before she can explain--

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I hear something. Girl straightens up. Her ear perks along her scalp. Malorie reaches out to the shoebox. Inside: The flutter of tiny wings. But otherwise silent.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Is it...

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I hear it, too. And now Malorie does. A faint but rhythmic CLAPPING.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Can you tell where it’s from? Neither child answers for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: It's getting closer. Malorie dips the oar back into the water--  26. It yanks in her hand, nearly slipping. The current is fast. And now we see what’s making the noise. A sunken BOAT, its deck still partly surfaced. Part of a human skeleton dangles from a cabin door. This vessel is big to navigate these shallow waters, and now it’s debris Malorie’s boat is on a collision course. And none of them sees it coming. Their blindness makes them eerily unguarded as-- The rowboat SMASHES into the shipwreck-- Lurching everyone and everything inside-- Malorie ballasts herself with the oar but-- A backpack tips overboard and then-- BOY falls off the back--

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Malorie! She felt it coming and snake-swift GRABS his leg through maternal instinct-- But hanging onto him starts to tip the boat over--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Boy! And Boy flails and splashes-- And Malorie lies flat and drops her oar but refuses to le of the Boy's jacket-- The boat hits a shallow point, slowing abruptly-- Boy manages to get his hands on the boat again, coughing water, his breath pluming in the cold air-- Girl is quietly having a nervous breakdown, her hands on blindfold, ready to pull it off-- Malorie gets both hands around Boy-- Hefts him back into the boat, soaking wet, crying, bleedi

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Malorie Malorie Malorie--  27.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Shh shh, I got you.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I’m cold.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Girl: a dry blanket. Girl still considers taking off her blindfold. Breathing quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Blanket. Girl reaches around in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I can’t find the pack. Just the food bag. Malorie searches, too. Realizes it’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Okay. She pulls a thin, folded blanket from under her, what she been using as a cushion, and drapes it over herself and B creating a little cocoon in the boat. The blanket is soak from the collision. It’s useless to dry the Boy. With the blanket fully covering both the boy and her ina makeshift fort, Malorie pulls off her blindfold. Boy is shivering uncontrollably. Hypothermia. His forehead is bruised.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What do I do? Boy tugs at his blindfold. Peers up at Malorie with one teary eye.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You need to dry off and warm up.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: B-blankets?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: We lost the rest, and this is too wet. So I’m going to get some more and bring them back. Okay?  28. Boy nods.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cover up. Fort goes away. He adjusts his blindfold. Malorie dons her blindfold, too. She lifts the blanket off and slaps it to the boat’s floo

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are we going back? What are we doing, are we going home?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Shh. Listen. I have to get some blankets. Should be in a house nearby. I won’t be long.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You're leaving us?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Sit back-to-back. Listen closely. The bird stays with you. Malorie shoves the row boat with her one remaining oar un it wedges against the shore. She then takes the soaked blanket. And very gingerly steps out of the boat. Boy’s teeth rattle and he makes a noise when he exhales.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shh. Boy screws up his face, mustering courage. Two steps into the woods, Malorie stops. Reaches out. Finds a branch. On her belt: a reel of fishing wire. Weighted at the end with a sinker. Malorie loops the end around the base of the branch. Tugs at it. It’s solid. She ventures into the trees. The fishing wire unspools as she goes. Pointing her back to the boat.  29. The reel makes a sound; soft clicking. Girl and Boy listen to it recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie moves with one arm out in front of her face and another panning left and right. She walks quickly, even blind. She finds a tree, then navigates around it. The reel clicks softly at her belt. A rustling sound. Malorie freezes. Holds her breath. Then the sound of flapping wings, overhead. Birds. Malorie breathes again. Visibly relieved. She marches on. Distantly: tiny bell-song from a wind chime. That suggests a back porch. A house. Another half dozen steps puts her into a clearing. Her foot nudges something. She crouches down. Feels. Stands up clutching a metal rod. Her hands work their way up the metal-- it’s long. She finds the end: A net. This is a pool cleaner. Malorie holds one end and reaches out to thump the ground ahead of her, in an arc. Soft thump... Soft thump... Concrete. Malorie advances in that direction. Ahead of her: A dilapidated two-story HOUSE. With a backyard pool, now scummy with algae. The cleaner dips into the green water. Splashes. Malorie course corrects to walk around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy is trembling so much, it agitates the budgie in the shoebox. Its wings flutter under the lid.  30.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Hush.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Please. Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Tell me something she would say.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Don’t click your teeth.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What if she doesn’t come back?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: She always comes back. But Girl’s voice cracks when she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (quietly) What if she doesn’t?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight pours in from bay windows, illuminating dust in stale air inside. The back door vibrates with a loud thump. Again. And then it’s forcibly kicked in by Malorie. She steps inside. Tense. All is quiet. It’s a five-bedroom mausoleum. Malorie finds a chair. And a table. It’s a breakfast table. Nearby: A counter. The kitchen. She takes a step deeper into the house-- And the fishing wire goes taut. End of the line. Malorie curses to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Malorie ties the reel to a table leg.  31. She unfurls the wet blanket, drapes it over herself. Under the sopping covers, she removes her blindfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very narrow world. Blanket, her feet, and some of the t floor around her. Just enough to navigate by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the sunlight on her back, Malorie delves into the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy’s sounds of agony are getting louder. Girl rocks back and forth, hugging herself. From the woods: Branches break. Boy instantly goes quiet. Girl grabs the oar. Both sit up like rabbits, listening for a predator. More branches crack. The sound bounces around the forest. No way to tell if it’s near or far.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (sotto) Is it her? It isn’t. From the shoebox: two nervous CHIRPS. The bird cannot see out the holes cut in the box, but it’ clear the budgie senses something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free of the blanket and blindfold, Malorie grabs a set of bath towels off a rack. Shoves them into a duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie opens dresser drawers, looking for clothing. Checks the tags on t-shirts. Takes one.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie rifles through clothes on racks. Finds a heavy coat. Too big. But better than nothing. Ready to go, she dons a clean, dry beach towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning to the kitchen. A noise stops her cold: The sound of the table being dragged across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fishing wire has caught on something. Something big enough to move the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight ahead, staring at the fabric of the towel, all t filters through is a vague rectangle of sunlight. And then a shadow passes in front of it. Large. Devouring the gauzy sunlight. Malorie goes rigid with fear. Slowly, she reaches up and puts on her blindfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beach towel slides off her back. She's gripping the scissors in one hand. Moves. Very. Cautiously. For the door. The table is jammed against it. Her hand finds the reel tied to the leg. The fishing wire is still taut. Straining. Poised to snap at any moment. Something splashes heavily, outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie stays low, following the line. Listening intently. Something is near. In the pool. What isn’t heard: breathing noises. It’s unsettling.  33. Malorie’s hand follows the fishing line. Her foot steps on the pool net she dropped before. Off to her right, more water sounds. Something emerging from the pool. Malorie does something very risky: She runs while blindfolded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thin tree branches lash her as she runs through. Then, she trips on something and falls hard. Scrapes her When she gets up, she reaches out, searching, finding: A CORPSE of a woman. Mostly decayed. But higher up-- The fishing line. She’s back on track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy and Girl huddle together, shivering. Malorie emerges from the trees-- Girl grabs the oar again, threatening:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Stay away!

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s me, Girl. It’s me. Malorie finds the boat and climbs on board. Boy and Girl cling to her. Hugging tightly. Malorie embraces them both. Beat. Then, sniffling:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Will we make it now? Boy tilts his head up at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Will we ever make it?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Of course we will.  34. She says it sternly. But her head is turned away. Like sh asked that question for years, every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years ago. An ‘X’ is drawn in a square. Long-haired Malorie crosses through a July date on a wall calendar, matching a week of Xs prior. She's at the counter separating the kitchen from the livi and dining area of the house. She flips the calendar to September to note the 28th circled and labeled: “DUE DATE Behind her, the living room is busy with the captive memb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg stares at an empty cabinet. Other cabinet doors hang open, revealing stacks of platew here and there, and lots of empty space. A rare can of fo Felix crunches on cereal right out of the box at the isla Standing and eating like a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Is that Choco-Burst?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Yeah man. If anything has my name on it, it’s this. Why do you even have this stuff? Gesturing at the box with the cartoon character on its co

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It’s my nephew's favorite.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: (mouth full) He has good taste.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (judgmental) He’s ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom nods at Greg as he approaches. Waiting for the answer  35.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We're out of perishables. And all that’s left to drink is well water. You might have to make another trip to Cheryl’s house and grab anything else there to eat.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We did that already. And the two houses on either side.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We need a real solution here... As they continue, we drift to find Lucy playing solitaire the coffee table. Her leg bounces. Cheryl rearranges the throw pillows on the couch, making chatter with Lucy whether Lucy wants to or not.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: And if I hadn’t been out to check the mail, who knows where I'd be. What were you doing around here? Lucy tries not to take it as a racist question.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I live a mile from here. I’m in graduate studies.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Oh? Maybe you know Felix, I hear he’s a recent grad.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Pshh. No.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: What are you studying?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Fitness and nutrition. So basically I’m screwed. Nobody’s gonna be counting calories anymore. Cheryl moves a chair and sits at eye level with Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: This is temporary. When we get out of this, I’m going to have you help Bobby with his candy addiction. (at Donald) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have they said anything about Lansing? Donald holds up a finger at Cheryl: hold on. He sits near stereo system tuned to a talk radio station. Felix returns from the kitchen and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...would then move north from Ann Arbor securing smaller cities as they go, starting with Brighton, July 27. Fenton, July 30. Waterford, August 10. Flint, August 17. Riverbridge, September 3.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: There it is.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Malorie, circle September third.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: National Guard?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Yeah. Malorie-- still at the wall calendar-- circles the date. writes the word “RESCUE” on the date.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Allegedly. Lucy stands up and rolls her shoulders like a boxer befor fight. Nervous energy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: September? Fuck, that’s over a month away. Cheryl gives Lucy a disapproving look. Lucy ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: We'll run out of toilet paper sooner than that.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: We've already cleaned out the kitchen. Some of us don’t understand rationing, either.  37. Malorie joins in, having overheard Greg and Tom nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom is talking about a supply run.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: The radio said to stay inside.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Stuff won’t magically come to us.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Somebody must deliver out here. (off everyone’s looks) I mean, right? ...What? Felix is first to crack a laugh. It gets everyone gigglin

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Cheryl. Nobody delivers anymore. The doorbell rings. Everyone tenses. Exchanges looks. Greg and Tom break from their talk and join the group.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Was that...? The doorbell rings again. Nobody moves.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well is someone gonna get that? She goes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Is that safe? Lucy stops at the door. Hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You think it’s one of those things?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: (oh come on) Ringing the doorbell? Like they’re selling cookies?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muted) Nobody's answering.  38.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Who’s there?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh thank god. Hi? My name is Olympia. Can we come in?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What are you doing out there? Greg marches for the door--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh for god's sake, let her in. But Tom advances, grabbing a blanket from the back of the sofa on his way--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Wait, hang on. (through door) I’m going to open the door just a little and hand you a blanket. There are two porch lamps on either side of the door, you need to hang this on ‘em to block the view, okay?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to room) Look away. They obey, as Tom opens the door a crack and tosses the blanket outside, then closes it again. A moment later, after some shuffling outside:

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay? I think it’s up now. Tom opens the door just a crack and peers outside. Throug the narrow view of the front porch: A woman. Blonde, put together. Carrying a Hello Kitty tra bag full of clothes. A timid 30 going on Sweet 16. A scar hides her face. She pulls it up and blinks at Tom. OLYMPIA (CONT’D) Hi. Tom opens the door for her and she steps in.  39. OLYMPIA (CONT’D) Oh wow, there are a lot of you. She sets her bag down, revealing her round belly under he dress. She’s pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You're... uh. Olympia nods, caressing her bump.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Due September 20.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Wow, you two are a week apart. Malorie and Olympia make eye contact. Malorie instantly dislikes her.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: My husband is in the Air Force, he was deployed last month, so I was staying at a friend’s down the block the day everybody started freaking out. She went out to get groceries, uh, that was two days ago. So I went outside, and-- Tom starts to shut the door when a HAND pushes back, keep the door open. In steps EDGAR: 60s, weathered and scarred, facial hair, war veteran’s thousand-yard stare. Dressed for mountain hiking. Wearing dark shades. He plants his feet next to Olympia and takes off his shad OLYMPIA (CONT’D) .»--and I ran into Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What were you doing outside?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Is it safe to go out?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Don’t be stupid. Felix looks to the others: What the hell?  40.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You listen to me, and listen good. There are at least two of those things out there. Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Are they hostile?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: They don’t have to be. Looks like you all got a good thing here. Keep it that way. Stay the hell inside.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How do you expect us to get resupplied?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: With your eyes closed. Nearest store is the Super Target, five blocks south, two blocks west. Had plenty of food as of Tuesday. Find the curb, follow it. And keep your goddamn eyes shut. Who’s the owner?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: You got an attic?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s uh, we made it a game room for my nieces--

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Whatever. That’s where I’1l be. Edgar starts up the stairs. Donald calls out:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Hang on, old man. You talk like you dealt with those things out there. Edgar levels his glare at Donald.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: You don’t “deal” with ‘em, you avoid ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What the hell are they?  41.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Devils. Monsters. Spirits. Take your goddamn pick.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Which is it?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: So you don’t know anything, really.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: That's how they get you. They wait around for you to get curious. They don’t gotta lift a finger to kill us off. Our need to know will do it for ‘em. With that, Edgar disappears upstairs. The room listens to footfalls all the way up to the attic floor, until a door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Um. Do you have any food? Everyone returns to the immediate problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Scrabble boardgame sits on the coffee table and Tom sha a velvet bag in his hands. The contents click like plasti pieces rattling together. The rest of the group is gathered around Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We need to get enough supplies to last to September three. That’s all we gotta do. National Guard rescue day. I’1l volunteer to go but I figure we need at least four to make it quick and safe.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Tom, you’re a nice guy, but I don’t think anyone else is gonna volunteer to go out there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: That’s what the tiles are for. Draw a letter ‘E’ and you’re exempt. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But there are three ‘S’ tiles. Draw one of those, and you’re going shopping with me. All right?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: So it’s just random?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: That makes it fair.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: (muttering) I’m never good at these games. Tom holds out the bag for Cheryl to draw first.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Go on. Cheryl reluctantly reaches in... Pulls out a tile. Reads Lets out a breath. It’s an ‘E’. Tom faces Donald next. Donald reaches in. Pulls out with hand in a fist. Opens his palm: another ‘E’ tile.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Exempt. Tom offers the bag to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You next.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Fine. Lucy reaches in. Pulls out a tile trapped between two fingers. Angles it so she can see: Another ‘E’ tile. Tom shakes the bag and offers it to Olympia next.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: I have to do this too? I was just out there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're all in this together. Olympia looks from face to face, searching for sympathy. Finding none, she draws a tile.  43. In her palm: an ‘S’ tile.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: This isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It’s the only way to be fair. Donald speaks like someone already exempt.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Since no one’s gonna be the gentleman, I’1l do it. Here. Lucy takes Olympia’s tile and gives her the exempt one.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t see why not.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1) Greg draws an ‘E’ and lets out a breath. 2) Felix draws an ‘S’ tile.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just one more now. 3) Edgar throws a tile on the table and stomps off. 4) The tile on the table: another ‘E’. Exempt.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: The last one to draw.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Well. I guess we know. Tom upturns the bag and the remaining ‘S’ clatters. She looks around the room, hoping for a volunteer trade. The other exempt members don’t dare meet her look.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Sorry, Malorie.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What I want to know is how you plan on making the trip. Tom grins, ready for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON A CAR: A Cadillac. Upper-middle-class luxury. Bu American. The product of living close to Detroit. Tom climbs in. Others from the group spill into the garag trying to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: You're gonna drive there?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s faster. Easy to stay together. And it’s safer.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: How is it safer to drive blind? Tom starts up the car. The in-dash GPS navigator boots up. Tom smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We're not blind.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: - Tom cuts up a cardboard box with a pair of scissors. - Black electrician’s tape spreads over the windshield. - The top of a pillowcase catches as a window seals up. - More tape secures the pillowcase to the window. - Tom removes the rearview mirror with a wrench, to remov any tape-gaps in the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom's last flourish: taping over the tiny camera above th license plate on the back. Tom stands with his arms crossed, nodding at his work. Lucy, Malorie, Donald and Greg all stand with him. The Cadillac looks like a makeshift meth lab. Every window is blacked out with cardboard, tape, and lin Lucy checks it out more closely.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: It's like a car for vampires. (grins at Tom) Cool.  45. Tom opens the driver’s door, climbs in, and starts the engine. The Cadillac thrums to life. The interior glows from the light of the electronics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still idling in the garage, driver door ajar. Tom sits at the wheel. Malorie sits shotgun. In back: Luc and Felix. Lucy carries a golf club with her, and Felix h armed himself with a hand-axe. Greg hands Tom a sticky note from outside Tom’s door.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I made a list, going by your math. Get as much as you can.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Will do.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: The store address is eleven oh one Longview Street.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Already in the system. Now get inside, and I’1l raise the door.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Okay. I... Good luck. Tom nods and shuts the car door. The interior feels more a submarine, lit by the dome light. Malorie pulls out a slip of paper. Considers it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What do you have there? She holds it out for him.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: This is where my parents live. I was going to check on them--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Malorie--  46.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: --and I just, I haven’t heard from them and I know it’s out of the way but I just need to know. I’m sorry--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. He takes her hand with the note and closes her fingers ov it. Tom isn’t taking the address. He’s having her keep it But he’s being tender with her about it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I get it. I do. We all want to know about someone. But we have to get used to not knowing. Or else we won't make it. Okay? Malorie takes a ragged breath and nods. Tom reaches up and presses a button on a remote. Click! The group listens to the sound of the garage door opening Tom touches the navigation screen.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Calculating route. A map appears, with a thick red line forming an L-shape a the streets. Tom puts the car in reverse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rear bumper advances at us, reverse lights aglow. INT. GREG’S HOUSE - DAY Cheryl begins searching in drawers by the entertainment center, tidying up as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: So, are all of you, like, friends and family?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: We didn’t know each other before last week.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: That must be weird.  47. Cheryl chortles and nods like, “You have no idea.” Greg notices her peeking in drawers.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: This. She holds up a PHONE BOOK. Stonebridge is small enough it combo white pages/yellow pages.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What, as kindling?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: You all laughed at me about delivery, but I bet I can find someone who will, mm-hmn.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (to Olympia) Olympia, was it? What is it like out there? Were you attacked?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Do you know what those things are?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Just that when you see one, you go crazy. So, they’re bad.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: But is it just seeing one face-to- face? What about through a camera? Or video footage? How big are they? Why are they out there?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: I was hoping you guys had some information.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Just the radio. Local DJ. The big stations dropped three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I have an idea.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed in this room tells a tale. One half is turned down sloppily. The other half is a shr Pillows under the covers suggest a body. Atop the bedspre Lydia’s nightgown has been draped. And on a pillow at the head rests a framed PHOTO of Lydia. Greg stands at a small TV on a dresser. Holding a remote. Donald, Cheryl, and Olympia are gathered at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Home security system. Two cameras, in front and back. It’s wired through this TV. The image is thermographic, so it can pick up heat signatures at night.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Greg, hang on.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: The system stores the last twenty- four hours of footage. This is a digitized signal, showing just the temperatures of objects. It’s neutered information. Colors on a flat screen. Harmless.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: We don’t know that. Greg takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Lydia saw one. She must have. It killed her. So, if I can track them like this, just looking at a few thousand pixels of light, then...

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m getting some thermographic goggles, and a gun, and I’m going to kill every last one of them. Donald steps back a bit. Watches Greg. Cheryl speaks up:

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Or maybe we let the army do that.  49.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: That’s what Tom said. He said it wasn’t worth the risk. Are we doing just what Tom says now? Beat. Donald pricks at this. Greg looks at Donald as if expecting it to.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Tom doesn’t get to make that call. You do. Here is what we should do.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Greg is tied to a chair with extension cord. Donald tugs the ones around Greg’s torso. Tightening.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Double knots on the back?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Yeah. You sure this is the sturdiest chair in the house? Greg's arms are strapped to the chair’s arms. But he has control of the remote.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yes. Loosen the wrist a bit so I can use the clicker.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Okay. Remember you can just turn off the TV, at any time.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’1l call for you when I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: We'll be nearby. Okay? Donald pats Greg on the shoulder and leaves the room. Greg stares at the TV screen. It shows bluish coverage of the front and back of the hou In the upper corner, a label: “REPLAY MODE.” The screen flickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GPS screen flickers, points Tom straight ahead.  50. Tom drives. Malorie watches the map closely. The arrow. The map goes away, replaced with a diagram of the car, al flashing at the front right bumper.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Proximity sensor. Tom steers around it.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Probably a parked car. Yeah. Gonna be cars up and down. The Cadillac's left tires brush against something. Curb. Tom corrects again. Keeps driving.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: In, half a mile, turn right. The proximity sensor warns: front bumper. Tom tries to steer around it, but not fast enough. The front end rises half a foot, then drops again, runnin over the obstacle. The back end follows. Malorie gives Tom a look. Tom glances her way.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Don’t think about it. From the back seat:

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: What was that? A speed bump? Malorie and Tom don’t say what they’re thinking it was. Outside, through the windows, the group can hear the stat hiss of a hydrant leak as they drive past it. Water pocks the hood, roof, and right side. Tom keeps going, white-knuckled.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Turn right, here.  51. The map points the way. Tom turns slowly. The proximity sensor beeps: Left front corner. Tom adjusts. Goes again. Beep. Right front corner. Tom steers. Backs up. Looks for another route. Beep. Rear bumper. Tom puts it in park.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There’s something, I don’t know, probably a truck...

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Keep going around. Tom goes for the shifter. Something crashes, outside. Glass breaks. Everyone remains quiet. The car idles. Then: Beep. Front bumper proximity. Growing more incessant.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Someone else driving?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shh-- Beep-beep-beep-beep. The front end of the Cadillac sinks. Metal warps. A heavy weight advances along the car.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Oh god, oh god-- The group looks up: Dents form in the roof. The middle bows. A muted, rhythmi RASPING carries heavy from outside. Felix sweats, his hand gripping the axe.  52. The roof bows over the back seat. Lucy holds up her golf club at it, as if to prevent the r from caving in. It trembles in her hands. Everyone in the car is on the verge of panic. Then the rear end lowers. It’s walked onto the trunk. Lucy and Felix look back at the rear window, even though walled off with tape and box lids. Glass cracks. And then, out of the tense silence: BEEP-BEEP-BEEP. Rear bumper proximity. Suddenly: something strikes HARD at the back window-- The taped glass caves inward from it-- exposing the outsi

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Don’t look back! Tom puts the car into gear. And he drives straight ahead. Alerts be damned. Sunlight pours in from the partly caved-in window-- The side-view mirror bashes something. Tom keeps going. He pops a curb. The car lurches.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In one hundred yards, turn left. Tom speeds up. Driving faster.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Turn left, here.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom, just slow down-- Tom yanks the wheel left, the car ascends a short ramp-- And the whole car jostles from another curb bump-- And then Tom brakes hard. The tires screech on asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You have arrived.  53. They all catch their breath. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Now... we just have to go outside. Tom brings up a blindfold. Ties it. Malorie covers her eyes with a sleep mask. In back, Lucy dons a ‘do-rag for a blindfold. Felix puts his motorcycle helmet, its visor painted black. The four sit there with their hands on the doors. No one wants to step out first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some lights are still on. But the place is eerily quiet. Tom, Malorie, Felix, and Lucy enter the store.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shut the door behind us. Lucy and Malorie work together to slide the doors shut, w are papered with ads for some sale, covering any view of parking lot outside.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shh... Tom listens intently. Quiet is the reply.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m taking off my blindfold. He peels it off, blinks, and adjusts to the dimly-lit sto

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: .--Tom?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Form a chain together and follow. But keep your eyes covered. Tom grabs Felix by the hand. Felix reaches for Lucy, who turn grabs hold of Malorie. MOVING WITH TOM as he checks down every aisle, one at a t  54. Emergency lighting casts the warehouse-sized store in red amber. A handful of carts have been abandoned in aisles b otherwise the store shows no signs of disaster. Tom reaches the end, and his muscles relax.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're clear. The others take off their blinders and look around.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: It’s loaded. Tom smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Everybody grab a cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix grabs potato chip bags by the fistful. He tears one open and starts snacking. From somewhere else in the stor Tom calls out:

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stick to non-perishables. We need food that will last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy twists off the cap to a beer bottle and takes a swig

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Avoid bulky items. Remember we gotta pack this into the trunk. Lucy looks over at her cart: full of energy drinks and be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom marvels at the deodorants, shampoos and soaps. Grins.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m gonna be a hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix searches through boxes of cereal, most of which has been shoved around and mixed together.  55.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: C’mon baby c’mon... Yes! He lifts up a box of Choco-Burst like it’s a gold medal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy stands at a mirror wearing a wide-brimmed sun hat an holding up an evening gown to see if it’s her size. All o very dressy and upscale, unlike her workout clothes. She does a mock accent for the mirror:

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: My name is Cheryl. Don’t you have any Pelligrino?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie picks up a pack of sealed lunchmeats. Sniffs it. A shopping cart rolls into view behind her. Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Anything still good?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Maybe. If we eat it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Thought you might like this. He hands her a gift bag, complete with hastily-stuffed ti paper and a bow. And also still sporting the price code.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A baby shower gift. Malorie smiles and digs into the bag. Pulls out a classic baby’s pacifier. She’s happy. A small thing with a big gesture behind it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s lovely. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No doubt you and your husband already have one back home. Malorie tilts her head. Is he fishing?  56.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No husband. It was all casual until he knocked me up. But he didn’t want his “whole life turned upside down,” so he bailed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well. I bet he’s gotta be really inconvenienced by how the world has gone to hell now. He grins at her. Malorie laughs. Nods. Then the distant sounds of someone loading their cart pulls Tom back to:

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (checking list) Can you go and grab some batteries? The flashlights take double A. I’m gonna grab some clothes for people.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Aye aye, captain. Malorie pushes her cart onward and Tom turns his around. As Tom ventures back to the Mens department, Malorie look back at him. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie grabs batteries and tosses them into her cart. A fly buzzes past her. She sniffs. Something stinks. She approaches the end of the aisle. Wary. The smell is definitely coming from this end of the store Malorie brings up a flashlight. She rounds a corner. More flies buzz from a neighboring section. Malorie shines her light on the sign: “FOR PETS” She frowns, and advances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flashlight beam reveals a line of cages placed on she along one side. A trampled sign on the floor: “TODAY ONLY / ADOPT A PET!” Some cages hang open. Empty.  57. The flashlight glimpses shapes in others. Matted fur. Blo and feces. In this low light it’s hard to tell if they ar cats or dogs. Malorie winces, covering her nose and mouth. And then she hears it. A small CHIRP. She turns back. Sweeps the light. Finds a bird cage at th end, covered in black silk. Malorie lifts the veil and peers inside: Six fat, little BUDGIES turn their heads at her. One hops over to her side of the cage.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You made it. You cute little guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix wheels his cart up next to another cart. The abandoned cart is filled with canned goods. Toilet pa Freeze-dried foods. A lot like his cart. Felix reaches over and touches one of the thawed packages and his fingers are wet.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Guys? (louder) Hey, is someone here? A POUNDING on a door stops him short.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (tense) Guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four loaded shopping carts converge at the back by the de Tom, Malorie, and Lucy get to Felix.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: I think someone’s inside.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Inside where? More POUNDING. Nearby. Felix points--  58. Tom shines his light past a cleared-out butcher’s counter The walk-in freezer door. Its HANDLE VIBRATES as somethin pounds from inside. Tom moves around the counter for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Tom steps to the metal door. It rattles in its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: WEAK VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let me out...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hello? The voice speaks again but it’s too muffled. Tom leans in closer. Puts a hand on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who's in there?

dialogues.speaker: WEAK VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open the door open the door hurry please hurry just open it... Tom puts a hand on the handle.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s trapped inside.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: So? Leave him there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to do that. He grips the handle. Lucy and Felix join him. Malorie stays by the carts.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Just a crack. So you can talk.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: All right. The POUNDING resumes. Tom slides the lock back and turns handle... He opens the metal door an inch...  59. And he leans his face to the edge but doesn’t look inside

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd you get locked in? Bloody fingers grip the door. Someone wheezes.

dialogues.speaker: WEAK VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They did it, they tricked me, they told me to do it then they left me to rot like raw meat-- By Malorie, the budgies all start CHIRPING madly.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Uh, Tom? Something--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Man) Calm down, tricked you?

dialogues.speaker: WEAK VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just open the door and let it out, let it loose let it see you see it-- The budgies flap their wings in a maelstrom of panic-- Something heavy presses on the metal door-- And then, the briefest glimpse of long FINGERS or TALONS an upper edge of the frame-- what_is that?-- Lucy, Felix, and Tom all lean against the door to keep it from opening further but-- THEIR SHOES slide on the floor an inch--

dialogues.speaker: WEAK VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It wants out IT WANTS OUT-- Malorie rushes in, using a cart as a battering ram-- It SLAMS on the man’s hand and he HOWLS-- The door then shuts all the way-- Tom slides the bolt locked again-- And everyone steps back. The budgies calm down again. INT. SUPER TARGET —- MOMENTS LATER The four form a train with their carts and hurry down an aisle back for the entrance.  60. The front cart suddenly gets caught on something and stop the forward momentum. Malorie moves around to push it out of the way and then g and steps back when she sees it: A dead man. Recently dead. Gripping a box cutter that’s stabbed into his own throat, wet blood around him. It’s JASON. The disbeliever who left their house on day o Tom urges them, pressing on:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheryl dusts with a dry cloth in the living room, listeni to Sinatra on the radio. Olympia watches her. Donald appl duct tape to the curtains in the living room. They’re all full of nervous energy.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Give him time. He’s got twenty-four hours of footage to watch.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Maybe they don’t get close enough to the house for the security cameras. You know? Thump. Thump thump. They all stop and look up at the ceil

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Is that...?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Oh no. Greg... More THUMPING overhead now. And then a sound. From Greg’s vocal cords, but not quite a scream. Something else. And it rises in pitch. Then it becomes clearer that Greg shrieking a word over and over: Donald’s name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THUMPING is shockingly loud now. Accompanied by crash and breaking, as framed photos in the room topple off wal  61. Donald reaches the door and puts his hand on the knob, re to rush inside, but he stops. Steps back. Greg has stopped HOWLING by the time Cheryl and Olympia c up. Olympia doesn’t reach the top steps, reluctant to get close. Cheryl starts to panic:

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: The TV faces the door. A final, sickening CRUNCH ends the THUMPING. Cheryl now t a step back as Donald grabs the doorknob again.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Greg? Greg just listen to me. Everything's gonna be fine. Just take some deep breaths, okay? No response. BY DONALD'S SHOES, blood seeps into the hall from under t door frame. Donald takes a breath and squeezes his eyes shut. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arms outstretched, eyes closed, Donald enters the room. The first thing to note is that the overhead lights are o With the sealed windows, the room is dark save for the wa flickering light from the TV, casting everything in blue.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Greg? Say something. Donald takes a step and nearly slips on the blood-slicked floor. But he gets his balance and keeps his eyes shut. Donald's foot brushes a chair leg. He steps over it... Past more pieces of the demolished chair. And then, in the glow of the TV: a severed finger by the remains of the chair. But no Greg. Donald gropes for the TV. It buzzes softly with power.  62. As he searches blindly for the cord, the screen becomes partially visible, at an oblique angle. The security footage has been paused, an image frozen in time. The thermographic video flickers and wobbles... But a SHAPE in shadow is nearly exposed on one side. Just when we're about to get a clearer view of it-- POP. Donald shuts the TV off.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, it’s off! (opens his eyes) Where... Cheryl leans in, reaches to the light switch and flips it And then SCREAMS in shock at what she sees: Greg's broken, mutilated body. Hanging from the canopy be like a giant insect caught in a spiderweb, his broken leg and arms twisted at inhuman angles, the rope caught on th bedposts, gouging into his bloodied neck, suspending him. Blood trickles onto the framed photo of his wife. And the distant mechanical sound. The garage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage door lowers behind the Cadillac as it pulls in The door reaches the ground... and then Tom and the other climb out of the beat-up car. Malorie takes the bird cage out on her side and makes eye contact with Tom on the driver’s side. She notices his attention to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What is it? Tom feels the hood and roof. Traces the indentations.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
