dialogues.text: It has feet. And it’s heavy. (to others) Two things we didn’t know before. Cheryl enters, pale and trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened to Greg. Tom frowns and leaves. Lucy and Cheryl follow. A can of yellow corn rolls to Malorie’s foot. She picks i and stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blindfolded, Malorie opens a can of cold pork-and-beans. Jabs a plastic utensil in the can. She scoops out a spoonful. Holds her hand out.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Scoop. Girl reaches out her hand. Finds Malorie’s wrist. Guides the spoon to her mouth. Girl taps Malorie’s wrist gently. And Malorie knows to refill the spoon. Right now, no one rows. Malorie feeds Boy next.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boy. Scoop. Wrapped in blankets, he reaches out, guides the spoon. Takes a bite. Taps her wrist. She pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: My hands and feet feel like, like needles. Poking. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Remember your job. Listen. With both ears. (beat) Girl. Scoop. Girl takes a bite. Chews.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Malorie...  64.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yes, Boy.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Why did God give us eyes?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: To look.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: But, we can’t really look. You taught us to wake up with them closed. Why give us eyes at all? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: To give us hope. Boy ponders this answer. INT. GREG’S HOUSE - FIVE YEARS EARLIER - NIGHT Pressing in on the back door, set into a “mud room” off t kitchen, with a place for boots, heavy coats, etc. Malorie (long-haired, seven-months pregnant now) enters f outside, carrying a paint bucket filled with water. She’s also wearing a blindfold. Her breath plumes in the night Just as she shuts the door behind her, we catch a glimpse the setup: The back door has a tarpaulin hood covering vi of the outside, attached to a small awning, so it creates little cocoon just outside the door. Malorie sets the pail down, takes off her blindfold, and reaches over to one wall... ...-where a large WHITEBOARD hangs with a set of instruct

dialogues.speaker: WATER WELL SCHEDULE
dialogues.text: 35 steps from back porch follow the chain (left of door) handle cranks AWAY = up, TOWARD = down everyone participates! Below is a list of names with check marks by their names indicate the number of water trips they’ve taken. Malorie puts a check mark by her name.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water pours down a funnel from the pail into a plastic ju Malorie then gets a glass for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie sits on the couch, drinking the water. Her attention drifts to the coffee table, where the landl phone sits alongside the Stonebridge phone book. She scoots the book toward her, flips through the pages. And then picks up the receiver. Holds it to her ear. Remarkably, there is still a dial tone. (This is probable only with old landline telephony. ) Malorie flips to the yellow pages section and finds a lis for the hospitals. She starts dialing. Behind her, over her shoulder, the open kitchen area. And farther still, the back door in the mud room. That area i unlit now, but the white of the back door stands out. And the door starts to open. Malorie doesn’t hear. She’s busy trying numbers. PRESSING IN on Malorie as she dials and listens for a wor number on the other end, edging out the view of the door the kitchen as something gets closer... Then that sound. That otherworldly, inhuman noise. Malorie’s whole body goes rigid with sudden fear. She snaps her eyes closed and leans down into the couch t try and hide. Her shallow breath is overtaken by the sound of rasping. Close on her face, eyes firmly shut, and then-- Two ragged FINGERS with wet, black talons on the ends rea in and press against her cheek and eyebrow. Malorie whimp in shock, tries to turn away from the contact, but then--  66. The fingers spread, pulling her eyelid open, forcing her look directly at the thing-- Her pupil contracts in terror-- And for a singular frame we see: A wide-mouthed, pale, we FACE with bulging eyes like a deep-sea monster, then-- INT. MALORIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Malorie wakes up from the nightmare, breathless. Her hair is damp with sweat. It takes her a moment to calm down. Olympia snores softly in the neighboring bed. Malorie reaches for a glass on her nightstand. It’s empty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie descends the stairs with her empty glass, headed the kitchen. She passes the front door... A moment later, there’s a VOICE from outside.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anyone? Hello? Malorie freezes. Tense. Waits it out. A pause. Silence. Malorie turns, shaking her head, then:

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help, is there anyone? Malorie goes to the door and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Someone there?

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh god, oh thank god. The sound of boots on the wood planks of the front entry. Fumbling sounds of the blanket insulating the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Who is it?  67. His voice rises at the end of his sentences, so sometimes they sound like questions.

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My name is Gary? I’m, I got lost scavenging for food and, hello? Is this the front door?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is it? Shit, it’s been hours... Malorie looks upstairs for help. No one else is awake. Sh hesitates. Then remembers the budgies. They slumber in their cage, a few paces away. Unfazed. Malorie double-checks by picking up the box and holding i close to the door. She whispers to them:

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (to budgies) Is it safe out there?

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please. It’s cold. Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: There’s a protocol. I can’t let you inside right now. You have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I fell and I’m bleeding. I can’t see how bad it is? I don’t want to bleed to death, please... Malorie sets the box of budgies down and debates with herself. They didn’t consider someone with an injury when they made the rules. She closes her eyes, then opens the door. GARY (late 30s) steps in. Tall, wearing a flannel jacket. Could be a truck driver. Also blindfolded. GARY (CONT’D) I’m in. He helps her shut the door. Then he takes off his blindfo His arm is badly cut, matting his flannel jacket. He noti it and sets down his backpack, to ease out of his coat.  68. GARY (CONT’D) Okay, so yeah, I’m gonna take this off. And then maybe you have some gauze or a towel or something? Malorie hurries to the powder room and returns with a thi hand-towel.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I’m Malorie. Gary takes the towel and wraps his wound. The cut is long not deep; superficial.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Pleasure. Thanks. (notices) Wow, you’re about ready to pop.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Where have you been staying?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Over on Lincoln? Like maybe quarter mile that way? No, this way.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Alone this whole time?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No. What about you? Are you alone? He looks back at her. The question is unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s awake now, sitting around the room: Malorie an Olympia, Lucy, Tom, Don, Cheryl, and Gary. Gary holds cou

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: My brother has always been that guy. You know the one? With the disaster “go bag” and the ammo reloader for his AR-15? He was always sort of an asshole, but I knew I’d be safer with him than anywhere else. By the time I got there he had six other guys all staying with him, hunting buddies. Eddie-- my brother-- he had blankets on the windows, but they were ready to arm up, go out and bag them a monster.  69.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How’d that work out for them. Gary shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Two of them went out, never came back. But we let this guy in? He looked lost, said his wife and kids just... he was alone. That... changed things.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Who was he?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Just some guy. Carl? That was his name, I think. Kept to himself, didn’t talk much, wouldn’t join the group for meals. I think he was scared of my brother’s friends. Gary takes a breath, knowing where his story is going. GARY (CONT’D) The one time he did join us, he said something. He believes this whole thing is a hoax. There are no creatures, or whatever, out there. And we're all being tricked. Of course that didn’t go over well with anyone else, and he shut up after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary and six rough-and-tumble MEN sit around a dining roo table, passing a bottle around. It’s a frat party for mid aged men. Gary tries to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The guys raided a liquor store and we all celebrated that night. INT. EDDIE’S UPSTAIRS HALL - FLASHBACK — MORNING Gary approaches the stairs down to the first floor. His clothes are disheveled.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I can’t drink like they do. I passed out upstairs at some point. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when I went back down to beg my brother for some aspirin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to scene.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Carl had pulled down all the blankets and left the doors open. Olympia gasps.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know it was Carl, and not any of your brother's friends?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: My brother and his friends are all dead, in that house. But Carl... He left. And he left the door open behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: How is that even possible? I mean, everyone who’s seen one of those things...

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What if he was already insane? We don’t know what it does to you if your mind’s already broken. Maybe it doesn't affect you. Maybe it can affect everyone differently.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Like that guy in the freezer at the store. Shit... Bad enough we gotta worry about monsters or whatever the fuck they are. Now this? The group erupts into conversation. Donald pulls Tom out the group for a sideline talk.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Aren’t you worried?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: About what?  71.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Old man Edgar. He keeps to himself, always getting paper, his fingers have charcoal stains... Didn’t you hear Gary’s story?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Tom, yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He’s been here for weeks without incident. He’s harmless.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Or he’s a time bomb. Donald walks away. Tom stays, struggling with the issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie brushes her hair after a shower, prepping for bed Olympia enters with a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: I’m going right back to bed. Olympia opens the medicine cabinet and grabs three pill bottles. Vitamin supplements. Pre-natal prescriptions. Malorie notices. Inspects a bottle, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Where’d you get the pre-natal supplements?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: I had them on me. Malorie suddenly feels like the worst mother ever. She st combing out her hair and stares at her reflection a beat. Olympia jars her out of her silent shame-- OLYMPIA (CONT’D) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: For what.  72.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: For coming over here. I hear what Don says about us. One pregnant woman was a problem, two is too much. I’m a burden.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Yes I am. I’m so used to my husband handling things. He loves me so much... I got soft from all that love. Forgot how to do things. Now he’s out there, and maybe he’s flying jets but, I mean... Olympia tries really hard not to cry. It’s clear now, she feels like the unprepared one, and sees Malorie as better Malorie moves to comfort her. Takes Olympia’s hand in her

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Hey. It’s going to be all right. Olympia smiles with a sadness at Malorie.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: If something happens to me, I want you to care for it. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: It’s your baby.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that means much anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (emphatic) It’s going to be okay. We’re going to make it. All of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years later. Just Malorie and the children. Girl and Boy perch at either end of the boat. Malorie rows. All of them are still blindfolded.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Children... I need to tell you about the waterfall. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (breath) This is the hardest thing we have ever done together. One of you... One of you needs to be brave--

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Shh. Malorie frowns. Cranes her neck.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispered) You hear that? Now they all strain to hear. And there it is: an outboard motor. Getting closer. Malorie rows back for the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Keep your heads down. She finds the shallows. Just as the engine noise gets even louder. Like it’s moving for them. Malorie grips the oar tightly. Girl and Boy listen.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Do not take off your blindfolds. The boat’s engine cuts abruptly. The air smells of gasoline. Footsteps cross what sounds like a deck.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello there! (beat) Hey you three, it’s okay. You can remove your blindfolds, I’m just an ordinary man.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto, to children) No you cannot.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s nothing out here with us, Miss. We’re all alone.  74. Malorie is still. Tense.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: ...-How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss, I’m looking right now. I’ve had my eyes open the entire trip today. Yesterday, too.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You can’t just look. You know that. The stranger chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Really, there’s nothing to be afraid of. Not anymore. Just us two on the river, crossing paths. Girl puts her hand to her blindfold. Toys with it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You can leave now. She hears the man sigh.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s no need to live like this. Consider these children. They're missing a chance to view a brisk, beautiful day. Malorie is trembling. Full on fight-or-flight mode.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Stay away from our boat. The man does not answer. Then: splashes in the water. Nearby. Malorie raises the paddle. Her only defense.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miss, the view is incredible. When’s the last time you looked outside? Years? Have you seen this river? The sun?  75.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: We are keeping them on.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I gave that up yesterday. I moved on. You can do it, too. His voice is closer. Wading.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Leave us alone. Girl keeps a hand on her blindfold. Head crooked in the direction of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They can’t haunt you forever. They can’t force you to live like this. (closer now) Your worries only keep you safe long enough to worry some more. The Man’s HAND reaches the front of the boat. His body near Girl.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And I’1l1 tell you what... His MOUTH speaks near the Girl’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve seen one. Malorie grabs Girl and pulls her close. She makes a soft yelp in alarm. They hear the man laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They aren’t as ugly as you’d think, Miss. Just, well, no way to describe them. You gotta see one. The Man’s arm reaches in, moving to caress Malorie’s chee She senses it a moment before-- And swipes with a survival knife in her fist-- Suddenly it’s a closed-quarters fight-- The Man trying to pull her overboard-- Malorie struggling, stabbing with the knife--  76.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Stay away from us--

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’1l1 make you all look-- He grabs onto the knife, tearing it from her grip. And Malorie shoves off the bank. Hard. The boat gets loose from the Man. He was too busy grappling for the knife. Malorie sacrificed it to escape him. And now they're in the current again.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes closed!

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you going to go? She's rowing now. Faster.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you going to cry every time you hear a stick crack? (shouting) Who's the crazy one? Kids, your mother is not well, take off those blindfolds! See the world! Malorie paddles. They're moving dangerously fast now.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What is the rule. Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I didn’t look.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I didn’t either. She brings them into a tight hug.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You did so well. They hug back. Beat.  77.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Malorie? Was that the man who sings all the music? Malorie lets out her tension with a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No, honey. No it was not. The faint crooning of FRANK SINATRA fades in-- INT. GREG’S HOUSE - DAY The living room radio plays the music. Returning to five years ago. The room is crowded with listeners, including Malorie, Donald, Cheryl, and Gary. The furniture in the room has been moved since last time. A thin line of SUNLIGHT slices into the room from the curtains hanging on the picture window. This is the only of sun in the room, possibly the whole house. At the bar counter leading to the kitchen, Lucy stands an stares at the calendar. September 3 has an ‘X’ through it along with the next two days after it. IN THE LIVING ROOM, Sinatra ends and the deejay returns.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well. That was the whole album. Probably my favorite of his. (beat) I don’t know if anyone’s listening anymore. No one’s talking, that’s for sure. Cell towers are dead. No chatter on the shortwave. September third came and went without a sign of the Guard. There’s a pause. Like the Deejay is out of things to say. Nervous at the silence, Cheryl stage whispers:

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: I wish we could call him.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It’s a digital switchboard. He doesn’t have a landline like us.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: How come the landline works?  78.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It’s a “land line.” Physical wires, not cell towers and satellites. And you don’t need juice to use them.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whatever is out there, maybe it got everyone. Maybe all that’s left is me, Sinatra, and those things. There’s a mechanical sound over the radio, and it prickle Malorie’s nerves. A slide locking. She goes to the landline phone on the end table. The phon book is opened to a page with the radio’s call-in number. Malorie starts dialing while the others listen.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Malorie, didn’t you hear what I just said?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I have to try. One more time.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is a lot I don’t know... Malorie paces with the phone, frantic.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Come on, come on...

dialogues.speaker: DONALD MALORIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing-- Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I do know one thing. Those monsters aren’t going to get the satisfaction of doing me in. (beat) Sing it, Blue Eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No, no-- Gary, turn it off, turn it off right now! Sinatra’s dulcet tones kick in. “Softly As I Leave You.”

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What? It’s fine. And then, muffled-- A GUNSHOT.  79. Everyone jumps as if electrocuted by the sound. Malorie slams the phone down in anger. This is what she w desperately trying to stop, futile as it was from here.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I told you to turn it off! Tom enters, hearing the flaring tempers.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What happened? Felix finds a dry humor way to it, trying to cope:

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Someone just ruined a perfectly good Sinatra song for me is what. (off Tom’s look) We lost our news guy. Overhead, the lights flicker Everyone looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Power grid has been down for days. We need to keep the generator running, and we’re out of diesel. Isn't that right, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: How long can we last with what we've got?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A day. Maybe less. The room erupts into ARGUING, voices overlapping--

dialogues.speaker: FELIX TOM
dialogues.text: --not even with meal --can’t point fingers now-- assignments--

dialogues.speaker: DONALD MALORIE
dialogues.text: --told you we are too many-- --just turn everyone away? It escalates quickly when Donald and Cheryl square off--

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: And I've been trying to keep the place tidy all week--  80.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: But that’s all you do, you just move furniture around and run the vacuum, you aren’t making a real difference here! Before Cheryl hisses a response, a sound shuts them up. The sounds of CHIRPING. The budgies. In their cage. Set b the front door. Everyone gets very quiet. Watching the birds freak out. Then: A SHADOW blocks the strip of sunlight from the pict window. Something looms close by. Olympia puts her hands over her face. Felix comforts her. everyone keeps waiting. The shadow leaves. The sliver of sun returns. And the budgies quit CHIRPING. Olympia spasms on the couch, snaking her hands around her belly. Grimacing in pain.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: That. That was a contraction.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: You’re not due for two more weeks. Olympia starts to panic at this statement. Malorie gives Donald a look: Shut the fuck up, Donald. Then she goes to Olympia and grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s fine, it’s probably just Braxton Hicks. You get those early, like little tremors. This starts to calm Olympia down again. She exhales slowl Tom addresses the group.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We need to make another run, right now. For fuel and any medical supplies to help with childbirth. I’1l volunteer. I need three more.  81. Tom grabs the Scrabble pouch and holds it out. Everyone looks at the bag with dread.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tom shouldn’t be the only one to volunteer. I'll go again. Not wanting to be outdone by Lucy, Felix steps up.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Fine. If she’s going so am I. And then Cheryl steps next to Felix.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: I’1l go. Said right at Donald with a glare. Donald gives her a look back: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: All right, so us four.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1) Lucy grabs a baseball bat from an upstairs exercise ro she’s claimed as her bedroom. A sleeping bag drapes over stationary bike and a knapsack hangs as a punching bag.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have a new plan. 2) Tom holds open a shoebox with holes cut in the sides. gingerly takes a budgie from the cage and transfers it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We find a manhole cover and take to the tunnels. If they’re clear, it gives us direct routes into town. 3) Felix tries on his motorcycle helmet. Waves his hand i front of his visor.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then we find our access points to gas stations. Grocery stores. Hospitals. We stock up. 4) Cheryl stands in the bathroom, staving off a panic att

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And we return home the same way.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheryl steps out of the hall bathroom, still full of drea Lucy catches up to her at that moment. Nearly passes her

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hey. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. (then) I don’t know how you do this. You're so... brave. And clever. Cheryl’s whole concept of who Lucy was has been demolishe It’s enough in this moment for Lucy to revise her views, She reaches out and puts a comforting hand on Cheryl.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I’m scared, too. Just like you. But we got this. Because we’re clever. Cheryl nods, mustering courage again.

dialogues.speaker: CHERYL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. INT. GREG’S HOUSE - DOWNSTAIRS BATHROOM - DAY Malorie washes her face with water she pours from a jug. She hears voices nearby. Leaning out the door, she spies- DONALD AND TOM facing off in the dimly-lit dining room, n a china cabinet of plateware no one will ever use.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: No one’s thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What are you on about this time? Donald speaks quickly with clenched teeth:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Soon we'll have two infants. That’s an added strain to our food supply, our medical supply, and fresh water supply, not to mention the noise of two crying babies could bring those things right to our door. What are you gonna do when that’s a problem?  83. Tom is done with Donald’s shit.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What’s your solution? Go on.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter, I’m not the leader. You are. They’re your problem. One day you'll have to tell everyone the only way to guarantee survival is to stab out your own eyes, and then we'll see how popular you are.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is that what this is about? Being leader? Fine, take it. It’s yours. Go tell everybody your plan. Donald balks at this. Starts to retort but doesn’t have a ready comeback. Tom slaps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, then how about you try to think in terms of group survival versus just your own. Okay? Tom leaves Donald to stew his own fear of leadership.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Maybe I will. Malorie, who’s seen this all, slinks out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back door, Tom is first to arrive at the mud room the supply run. Malorie approaches and hugs Tom. He hugs back. But she doesn’t let go. Into his ear:

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I read that when you hug for twenty seconds, it releases oxytocin into your system. Helps calm the nerves.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What did you do? Before all this.  84.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You really wanna know? (then, grinning) Optometrist. There goes my career. Malorie laughs. Nearly snorts. A genuine surprised laugh. It's infectious, and gets Tom giggling.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Oh my god! Ohh. I can’t remember the last time I laughed. Thank you. She puts her hand on his chest. He keeps it there. An unspoken invitation to tenderness. Malorie’s eyes sparkle

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And you? What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Whatever paid the bills until I figured out what I want to be.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: A mom?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Not really. I’m terrible at it. The budgie in the box near Tom TWEETS softly. Lyrically.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t think you give yourself enough credit. You’re a survivor, and survivors make good parents. (grins) Wouldn’t I make a good father? Malorie looks up at Tom. Wondering if he’s asking what sh thinks he is. She starts to reply, when Tom looks past he

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gary? Malorie looks back to find Gary standing nearby. Felix, L and Cheryl all arrive behind him.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I was thinking? You guys have been doing this for a while, and really I’m the new one around here, so I should go.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We could use one more.  85.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, I mean, I should go in someone’s place. Most of you have already done this at least once.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well. You don’t have to--

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: (eager) I’1ll stay. All eyes on Felix now. But he’s not ashamed of it.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Those things out there scare the shit outta me.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I thought you were going with me.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Only because you’re hot, but then I realized I’m gonna be blindfolded the whole time, so, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: All right, let’s go. Gary, get something for your eyes. (at Malorie) We'll be back in a couple hours. Malorie nods. The others gather at the back door. Lucy looks back at Felix, eyebrow arched.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You think I’m hot?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Well, I mean-- (owns it) Yes. Yes I do. Lucy points to him before she exits with the others.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Be ready when I come back. Felix realizes her meaning and looks to Malorie with a gr of surprise: “I’m gonna get laid today!”  86. EXT. GREG’S BACK YARD - DAY From the tarp-covered back door, a four-person chain emer on march alongside the house. Tom leads, followed by Lucy, then Cheryl, and Gary brings the tail. They walk with one hand on the shoulder of the person in front of them. All wearing some form of blindfo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie stays by the door, listening to Tom's voice leadi the group away.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tom better come back. She looks over at Donald, who’s been watching her.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Why do you care now?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: He’s the glue of the group. And most of you wouldn’t know how to survive on your own. Donald exits down into the basement, leaving Malorie cold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie sits down next to Olympia and returns to holding hand. Olympia smiles through her cramps.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Can we-- (breathes ) Can we do something distracting?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Anything. Malorie looks around and her eyes land on the phone book, next to the phone. She gives the book to Olympia and puts the phone in her l  87.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Here. Turn to the bookmarked page and read me the next number. Olympia opens the book to find PAGE AFTER PAGE of residen names either circled or crossed through. Stopping at ‘M.’

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I've been calling people, leaving messages when I get a machine. Maybe there’s a doctor out there, or someone who knows more about what’s going on. Anyway, it be nice to talk to someone new. Yeah? Olympia doesn’t argue. She finds the next name.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Bill Martinson. 980-1023. Malorie dials the number. Listens to it ring.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, yes, my name is Malorie. There is a group of us here in Riverbridge, on Shillingham Drive. If you get this message, call us back at this number. Please.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Julie Marx. 761-8811. Malorie dials another number. Listens. Waits. Shakes her at Olympia. Olympia marks through the name, but winces at the end of dropping her marker. Her eyes go wide-- OLYMPIA (CONT’D) Malorie. It’s happening now.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You sure? (off her look)

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s comin’ out. Malorie whips around to see EDGAR at the entry.  88. He stares at the two women, clutching a thermos in one ha The other shakes as if from Parkinson’s. And his fingerti are fully blackened from using charcoal sticks.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only one room with enough space for you to do it. The attic.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: The attic? That’s your room. Edgar keeps talking like it’s a done deal. Donald arrives time to hear Edgar’s speech:

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: We used a midwife for our two kids. You’re gonna need lots of water. Sponges. Towels. Surgical tools would help but I doubt you got those, so you can cut the cord with a pair of scissors an’ a coupla binder clamps. Malorie nods, feeling more uneasy by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: And a belt.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: A belt?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Give you something to bite down on. So you don’t scream. (leans in) There’s gonna be a lot of blood. Felix enters from the kitchen with a bowl of dry Choco-Bu

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: That right there? Is why everyone calls you “creepy guy.” Malorie puts the phone down and stands, now a live-wire o nervous energy.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: We can’t wait for them to get back.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix barges in, a man on a mission. Trying not to freak He grabs the bath towel hanging over the shower pole then puts it back, frustrated--

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Wet. He digs through cabinets and finds a dry wash cloth.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too small. Upstairs, Olympia MOANS in pain. Felix looks up, nervous. He decides to grab the floor towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie and Donald heft Olympia up the stairs to the atti She may be petite, but with the baby Olympia isn’t an eas carry. Donald tries being positive for once:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Doing great, just one more flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald and Malorie bring Olympia to the hardwood floor he straining in one last heave to set her down gently. FLUID SPLASHES around Malorie’s feet. Her water broke. Her eyes go wide. Donald notices. Realizes.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Oh shit. You too?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: But I’m not due for three weeks! Far downstairs, a door SLAMS shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix runs in carrying the floor towel and a pillow. Gary stumbles in from the back of the house, wheezing. Bleeding from his chin.  90.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Just in time! (beat) Where’s everyone else? Gary doesn’t answer right away. Tries to catch his breath

dialogues.speaker: FELIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gary... Donald hurries downstairs, grinding to a halt by Felix wh he notices Gary on the floor. Gary looks up and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: There was... was one in the... tunnels. We got separated, and... god, I just ran. Gary doesn’t want to make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: This just keeps getting better. (to Gary) Stay downstairs. You hear me? Gary nods. Overhead: Olympia’s CRY of pain. EXT. GREG’S HOUSE - DAY Angle on the third floor and the gray sky beyond. Olympia’s WAIL is joined by a second one: MALORIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix frantically fills a container with water at the sin Donald enters and starts pulling towels from a hanging ra

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Both of them?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: This is what you’d call a stress- induced birth.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Do they know about Tom?  gl.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: No. And they aren’t going to. Not until we get through this. Donald moves for the stairs with the towels--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olympia and Malorie lie on their backs on the floor, atop mattresses covered with beach towels. Both are sweaty, tr to control their breathing. A sheet covers Olympia’s lap, a throw covers Malorie’s. It’s raining, outside. Lightly. The rain tap-dances on th skylights above. There isn’t enough light to get a good s of the walls in the room. A lantern sits on a rolling table near the women. Curled by the lantern: TWO LEATHER BELTS, still with their Targe price tags stuck to the buckles. Malorie MOANS. And looks to Olympia. Olympia looks back. Scared.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: It’s happening. It’s really happening.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom? Tom! Donald arrives and sets the towels by a set of tools: A pair of scissors. A knife. Metal binder clips.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Tom’s not here yet, but you’re doing great. Both of you. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: What do I do, tell me what to do--

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Keep breathing. And push. With every breath.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure? He considers something. Tries to find the appropriate wor  92.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Do you, uh, want me to check, under the sheet, and see--

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No no! (breath) Okay yes, okay! Donald looks. Olympia squeezes her eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I can see the head, keep pushing! Felix enters, drops off the container of water. But it’s and narrow, no good for soaking towels or washing newborn

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: That isn’t the right-- never mind, stay with them, I’1l go get it. Donald rushes down the stairs, leaving Felix awkward and nervous with the two women. Malorie looks away, at the other wall... And sees Edgar standing just beyond the overhead light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald returns from upstairs and makes a bee-line for the large, shallow Tupperware container. The chaos and muffled sounds of footsteps in the attic ca still be heard down here.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: This is crazy. You don’t bring kids into this world. The sudden sound of heavy KNOCKING on the back door start Donald. He goes to the mud room and looks in... ...to see through the covered glass portion of the door: silhouette of a MAN. THE DOOR HANDLE wiggles. Trying to open.  93.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who’s there!

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tom! It’s Tom! Let me in! Something with the sound of his voice... it’s not like we heard Tom before. Ragged. Raspy. Donald starts for the door, but stops. Just like he did i front of Greg’s bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: How do I know you’re not crazy?

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because you’re an asshole! Beat. Donald nods -- yeah, that’s Tom. He reaches up to a shelf over the water-well whiteboard-- And grabs a SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: LOW ANGLE as Tom collapses on the floor of the mud room. and bruises mar his face. His coat is peppered with piece foliage as if he’s run through the woods. His blindfold barely covers his eyes. And he’s out of breath. The shotgun barrel descends into frame by his head.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gary said you were dead. Tom pulls off his blindfold. His eyes are wild with panic

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You let Gary back inside? The shotgun barrel lifts away... And now Donald is tense with a new fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary stands at a corner. His back to the room. Just standing there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from back of house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's hand reaches out and caresses a curtain. The budgies in the cage begin CHIRPING wildly.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK POPS
dialogues.text: 1) Gary SMILES as he yanks down the curtains in his broth house. There is no Carl. He then opens the door and somet LARGE begins to push through the quilt protecting the threshold. 2) Gary steps on the front porch of Greg’s house at night noticing the wan light leaking out of corners of covered windows. He then takes a knife and cuts his own arm, feig emergency to get Malorie to let him in. 3) Gary peels off his blindfold in the tunnels with Chery Lucy, and Tom. He SMILES as they all stop in their tracks the bird inside the box chirping and fluttering in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women push. They strain. They sweat. The blood vessels in Malorie’s eyes burst, making her loo extremely bloodshot. Felix keeps reading from the parenthood book’s chapter on childbirth part and checking on the women.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Little more... A muted BLEATING. Non-localized. Malorie stops pushing. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Is that my baby? Gasping for breath, the women both stop and listen. No, not bleating. SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: What is that? Felix stares at the attic door, behind Malorie. Unsure of what’s happening downstairs he placates them with:

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Okay ladies, keep going, come on--  95.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Is it out? Is it over? Something CRASHES heavily downstairs. And then the sharp, shrill SCREECH of someone’s voice. Another CRASH shakes the dust off the attic rafters.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Felix, please... Felix moves for the stairs--

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Don’t go please wait-- But he passes her, bumping the rolling cart with the lant The table drifts to the back wall as Malorie hears Tom’s footsteps down the stairs... The lantern illuminates the wall, exposing DOZENS OF CHAR SKETCHES OF MONSTERS. All shapes and sizes. Creatures wit hideous bodies and human faces. Things with no discernibl head or tail. Beasts inspired by snakes, and spiders, and squid, and grizzly bears. Thin, gangly beings with hollow heads. A coterie of teeth, venom, and unblinking stares. entire wall is papered with the artwork. Malorie shudders in shock at it.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: You all got stories. Mine is the worst of all. (leans close) Because I’m immune. Malorie gazes, wide-eyed, at the wall, and then at Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You've... seen one? Edgar nods. Nearby Olympia makes a noise as she pushes ag somewhere between a cry and a groan.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: (back at Edgar) You drew it? One of those things?  96. Edgar admires his work. Then faces Malorie.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: If only it looked like one of them. From downstairs, more SHOUTS, and then a thunderous GUNSH

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gary has pulled down the curtains! Malorie recognizes Tom’s voice and wants to get up right and go to him. But she can’t move from her bed.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Tom! Is that you?! Tom-- More loud noises downstairs. And then footsteps. The door opens, and Tom steps through. He looks unhinged, holding the shotgun Donald had moments ago.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: The babies are coming now? Malorie holds out her hand, and Tom goes to her side, gripping it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I’m early, we're both early, it just started and then my water broke and I don’t want it now--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey hey hey, shh, look at me. You're fine. You’re going to make it. Okay? And right now I have to go back down and stop Gary before one of those things comes in. Malorie tightens her grip on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Don’t go. Don’t go. Tom leans down and kisses Malorie on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I won’t let them hurt you. And then he leaves, shutting the door behind him. Malorie, in tears, shakes her head and calls Tom’s name, her voice is drowned out by Olympia crying out, and then-  97. A newborn infant’s cry. She’s had her baby.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: (to Malorie) Your turn. Malorie pushes. Her own baby gasps for air under the thro Nearby, Olympia pulls at the sheet over her lap, searchin for her baby. The old man reaches under the throw and lifts out Malorie child, still attached to the umbilical cord. Terrified of Edgar, Malorie takes the baby protectively--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Give him to me-- Edgar smiles with bloodied hands.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: It’s a boy.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Mine is a girl! I had a girl. She's laughing as she cries, in hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Starin’ down one of these things didn’t break me. Watching my wife turn on our two kids nearly did. She gored ‘em both with a kitchen blade, then cut her own throat. (beat) She sang to us as she did it.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Shut up shut up-- And then another heart-stopping GUNSHOT, this time from t second floor. And in that vacuum of silence... Sounds from the stairs. Creaking of steps. And the sound of the door opening. Edgar looks up, toward the door. And frowns.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Don’t you come up here.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: Tom?  98.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Don’t look-- Olympia looks. Still on her back on the mattress, she tilts her head bac look toward the stairs upside-down. Her eyes widen, and her mouth opens in a gaping smile. But with her head leaned back, it’s a macabre frown.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Olympia no no-- Olympia doesn’t blink, doesn’t look away from the thing a the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIA
dialogues.text: You're not so bad... You're not so bad at all! (then) You wanna see my baby? Malorie closes her eyes and puts her hand over her boy’s face. She calls out to Olympia--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Cover the baby’s eyes-- Olympia, please-- cover her eyes--

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Go on, get out of here. Git.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Please, please-- Olympia, just let me hold her for a moment... Olympia SNARLS. Chews on something just out of view, her hunched over her child. Malorie reaches out with one arm, keeping the other on he own baby, close to her chest. But she doesn’t open her ey

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're doin’ good, Malorie. Better than my wife did. Floorboards creak again. And then that raspy breath. Inch away. Close enough to agitate Malorie’s hair. Something wet tears. Splashes. Olympia’s bloody hand grabs a binder clamp.  99. The baby Girl’s face is covered by the bloody bedsheet.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Olympia... Talk to me... But she doesn’t. Instead, Olympia moves to the window. Malorie refuses to look. Edgar gets to his feet, his leg quavering under the effor Staring down the thing just outside view.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Nobody else is lookin’ at you today, now git. Trailing a chewed-through umbilical cord gushing vital fl from her insides, Olympia yanks a blanket off the window. Gray morning light hits Malorie in the face. She shelters eyes with her arm. The window creaks open.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing, woman-- Olympia climbs up and sits on the ledge, facing inside. She leans back like a diver going into the water-- And then falls out the window-- Edgar moves to stop her, but gets there a moment too late In anguish, Malorie screams--

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT OF HERE
dialogues.text: The thing just a few feet from her takes a step back. The stairs creak.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: That’s it, go on outta here. It retreats. Malorie still keeps her eyes closed. Messy w afterbirth. Her breathing shallow. Edgar leans close.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did it. Malorie shudders, clinging to her child. Edgar stands upr and sneers:  100.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was that new fella. Gary. Malorie doesn’t answer. She’s beyond words. Edgar limps for the door.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gonna have to put him down. At the top of the stairs, the old man looks back at the r a final time. And on Malorie, alone with the two infants. With that, he leaves. Malorie shakes from the trauma. She hears the baby Girl l out a weak cry from under the sheet. With effort, Malorie finally opens her eyes and zeroes in the place where the Girl has been hidden. She crawls to the other baby and cradles her with her own Malorie sits there. Holding the two infants. All is quiet. No birds chirping. No screaming or shouting. No crashing of furniture. The rain has stopped. Just Malorie and the two newborns. And then... A phone rings. Malorie’s posture stiffens. She waits. It rings again. She sees the scissors on the floor. The clamps. And the towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie descends, still cradling both babies. She wears a stretch of towel as a blindfold. The boy and girl are covered as well. And she’s snipped and clamped her umbilical cord. From the ground floor, the phone continues to ring.  101. Carefully, cautiously, she crosses the hall. Her foot steps on a body. In a pool of blood. Malorie trembles. And steps over the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie descends the last few steps and nearly slips on m blood in the entry. The front door hangs wide open. She passes by another body on the floor. The phone rings. For the tenth time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie sits down on the couch. Felix’s body is seated on the other end of the couch. But his head is missing. The phone rings loudly on the coffee table. Malorie’s hand reaches out... finds it. Just as it stops ringing. Malorie brings it to her ear, hopeful--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? A faint dial tone bleeds out, audible from here.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No... No no no-- She hangs up and presses asterisk-6-9. Holds the phone to her ear again, in time to hear the hig octave three tones preceding:

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) We're sorry but that number could not be reached. Please hang up-- With a trembling hand, she sets the phone down. And she begins to cry. With head in hands, she sobs. All the while, blood seeps toward her from Felix’s body.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun hangs low over the lawn, where a fire burns. A bonfire made of a pile of bodies. Malorie stands a dozen paces away, hearing it burn. She wears a scarf over her eyes. And carries a pole on her shoulders. Water jugs dangle from the pole. In this pose, in this light, she looks like Lady Justice. Among the burning bodies: The ADOPTION FLYER she took fro the hospital so long ago. “You have a choice!” It catches fire.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The months tick by: 1) Malorie opens the phone book, red pen in hand. 2) Malorie holds infant Girl in a rocking chair to the so of Frank Sinatra on the radio. The house is a mess. 3) A fire burns in the fireplace. The babies are close fo warmth. Malorie’s breath is visible. 4) The phone book. The final name in the Z alphabet. Last in the book gets a red line through it. 5) Malorie hangs up the phone in defeat. Utterly alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year later. The two crib-forts sit in the room. Covered by a blanket. Malorie arrives. Trembling. Holding a hypodermic needle in her hand. Outside, something bumps against the house. A tree, maybe. The wind. Malorie approaches the cribs. Draws back the blanket. Inside: Boy and Girl. Each maybe a year old. Asleep. Fitful sleep. Malorie cries silently. Reaches in with the needle.  103. The pointy tip is charred black from heat. Pointed straight down. Shaking in her grip. It hovers over Boy’s left eyelid. An inch. Less. Malorie’s fingers reach and open Boy’s eye. A breath from receiving the needle. Something creaks nearby. Something stirs. Malorie looks up and recoils in surprise. Girl sits up in her crib. Looking at Malorie. Head tilted. Just watching. Innocent. Confused. Malorie puts a hand to her mouth. Drops the needle. Slumps against the wall. A mess. For a long time, she sits there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes and nose red from tears, Malorie steps in. Stares at her reflection in the mirror. She reaches out, picks up a pair of scissors. Brings them to her face... And then starts to cut her own hair. PANNING to the mirror... It’s now the end of the haircut. Short-cropped. A warrior’s cut. Malorie hardens her face. She’s made a decision: Survival. But on her terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years later. Boy and Girl are both nearly the age of the opener. Playing with simple toys. Sounds of HAMMERING nearby. Malorie reinforces a wood plank over a window. Muscular arms. Still short hair. When she’s done, she steps back.  104.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: All right. Going out for dinner. You remember the rules? The children nod. Malorie nods back, like a sergeant. She crosses past a wall now covered with a giant Riverbri city map, likely taken from a municipal building. The map riddled with push-pins. She’s covered a lot of ground. Before Malorie leaves for the back door--

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Malorie?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yes, Girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you think you’1ll get to letter ‘K’ again today? The phone book rests open again on the coffee table. Its place marked by the pen.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: (beat) We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. Stillness. Malorie crouches, following a string. Her boots crunch under the winter ground. The string leads to a rabbit trap. Something furry caught inside. Malorie feels it: A dead rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie, still blindfolded, carries two dead rabbits tied together, marching cautiously toward the back door. Her hand searches for the fence line. Finds it. Her familiar landmark. She takes a breath. Distantly... A phone rings.  Malorie perks up. Hurries for the back door. Abandoning the rabbits. She gets to the back door. Struggles with the keys. Rinnnng!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings loudly in here. Boy and Girl stand arguing about it. A door slams and Malorie runs in--

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: We don’t know what to do!

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I got it-- She grabs the receiver and answers, breathless--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Hello, is this Malorie?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes, that’s me, yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) My name is Rick. I got your message.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Rick what?

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Holland. Malorie flips through the book to the ‘H’ entry. ECU: “Holland, Richard.” Circled in red.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Oh thank god. (emotional) Where are you, Rick? Are you safe? Are... are you with others? 105.  106.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're a community here. Seventy- three of us and counting.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Rick... Do you, do you have room for three more? Asked as if it were the most important question on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course. Malorie sits down. Suddenly weak-kneed. Boy and Girl huddle close.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where are you coming from?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Riverbridge. Upper east side, near state highway one-eighty.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) You'd have to take the river.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with the river?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catching up to the trip on the river. Late in the afternoon. The sun hangs low. Short-haired Malorie rows. Girl plays with her three puzzle pieces. They all hear something, ahead. Rapids.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Children? It’s nearly time.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: To look. This is what’s wrong with the river. Girl whips her head around at Malorie-- “look?” Malorie steadies the boat with the oar. Slows down.  107. Birds SQUAWK and CAW in flight overhead.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are many rocks here, and the water is shallow in places. But we need to land before the waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I thought we weren’t supposed to look. Ever. Malorie takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: This time is different. We can’t miss the first landmark. The statue. Remember the steps?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Eighty-six, forty-four, thirty.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Good. Landmarks?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Statue. Bridge. Car. Stone. A hundred migrating birds above them. All making noise now.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Malorie? Birds.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: That’s a good sign. It means everything’s all right. The row boat gently moves downstream. Overhead: The birds chatter, in migration. It’s a chorus of normalcy. The sound of the river rapids gets nearer.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're close. I am going to look now. Okay? Malorie grabs for her blindfold. Hooks a thumb underneath it. But a new sound gives her pause: The birds. They sound more aggressive.  108. The chatter becomes a psychotic symphony. CLOSE ON THE FLOCK in midair. They crash headlong into each other. They pick at their wings mid-flight. They attack one another. Beaks. Feathers. Blood. Drops of blood land on Malorie’s face. Around them: splashes. Everything is not all right. Birds dropping like feathered meteors. Boy and Girl tense up.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: They're falling out of the sky! A blackbird crashes into the boat with them. Wings convulsing. Neck broken. Then: Their boat suddenly stops with a jolt.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: We hit a rock. In the shoebox, their budgie begins CHIRPING. Girl stiffens in alarm. TIGHT ON her face:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (sotto) No we didn’t. The boat tilts slightly, from external weight. And then that god-forsaken sound, close to our ears: The signature, UNEARTHLY CRY of one of those things. Malorie, Boy and Girl clamp their hands over their ears. In the distance: A DOZEN MORE SOUNDS just like it. Malorie grips the oar-- Then stabs in the direction of the noise-- She comes in contact with something. Resistance.  109. In retaliation, it capsizes the boat. They all start to SCREAM as they go into the river--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malorie splashes in, toppled off the boat. BOY and GIRL drop in nearby, but travel faster underwater the current, their limbs wheeling for purchase-- Overhead, on the surface, the boat upends. Malorie reaches out for Boy as he passes by-- Her blindfold still around her face-- And then the water cavitates at Malorie’s leg and somethi SPLASHES in and grabs hold of her ankle-- But the foaming water and chaos is too much to get any so of distinct look at it-- is it a hand? A claw? It’s pale- Boy and Girl drift past, still carried by the water-- Malorie kicks hard-- gets free, goes up for air--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy and Girl cling to the embankment. Boy climbs to shore and helps Girl up.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Malorie! No response. FARTHER BACK, Malorie emerges from the water, gasping for air. Her blindfold has been torn away in the current. She coughs, keeps her eyes closed. Splashes behind her. Something advances.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you? Malorie launches in the direction of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Go! Find the statue! Boy leads Girl off the shore, reaching ahead still blindfolded, arm outstretched until it touches--  110. A FIGURE towering over Boy. Made of stone. The Virgin Mary, eight feet tall. Boy touches it. Confirms it. Then he calls out to Malorie:

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Here, it’s here! ON MALORIE, trying to zero in on Boy's voice. She changes course and moves for them--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Keep talking!

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're at the statue! Behind Malorie-- sound of something reaching shore. And farther back-- MORE splashes. Five. Ten. A dozen. All zeroing in on them. Boy and Girl stand at the statue, full of fear. Remarkably, Boy still has the shoebox with budgie inside. It CHIRPS in alarm, telling them what they already know:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: They’re coming! Malorie gets there first.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: I'm here, I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Malorie. I can’t run that fast. All three know that. The creatures are moving in. Malorie crouches down to speak close to them.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: You two follow the steps. Go. Now. Boy doesn’t need to be told twice. He grabs Girl and goes But Girl’s head still faces Malorie, asking:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?  111. Malorie stands up and faces back the way they came. At the sound of the dozen creatures closing in.

dialogues.speaker: COME AND GET ME.
dialogues.text: Then she turns and runs in a different angle from her kid BOY'S FOOT stomps the ground until it finds a paved path.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Start counting. He pulls Girl by the hand. STAYING WITH BOY AND GIRL as they run, Boy clutching the Girl counts to herself, her mouth moving-- Their feet slapping along a gravel path until-- Baseboards. Wood. A guard rail. A babbling brook. They're on a bridge. Still running. Girl’s arm cracks against the railing. Boy course-corrects. After the bridge the path intersects a road-- And ahead: a stalled CAR in the ditch.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Eighty-two, eighty-three-- They're early. Boy collides with the car. They both get their breath. Boy shouts back:

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Car!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are we going?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Wait. They breathe hard. FINDING MALORIE running blindly but full-tilt through tal grass, small branches of trees whipping her. STAYING WITH MALORIE like we did with Boy and Girl--  112. She keeps her arms outstretched-- Moving fast-- MALORIE’S POV Black. Her breath is hard and heavy. Her heartbeat is strong, palpable. The sounds of her feet crunching in tall grass. In one forward speaker, distantly: Boy’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Malorie! Malorie pauses. The monsters stampede behind her: A mountain of sound, crashing foliage, snapping branches. Getting closer. The sound of Malorie’s feet thump again until suddenly-- A GLIMPSE OF THE WORLD as Malorie trips into the brook ju few feet from the bridge, eyes flitting open on the way d

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh god--

dialogues.speaker: ON MALORIE
dialogues.text: Hitting hard in the brook, clamping her eyes shut again. But this is just a little stream full of rocks. Her arm i cut and possibly broken by the fall. STAYING WITH MALORIE again as she gets up and climbs the other bank of the stream. Breathless. Trees bend and fall into frame behind her. Crashing. One comes down frightfully close to her. A hailstorm of leaves descend around her.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep running!

dialogues.speaker: TREETOPS
dialogues.text: The monsters plow through the wilderness. Then sounds of them crossing the brook in pursuit. Always just out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: FINDING BOY AND GIRL
dialogues.text: Running. Along a corridor made of barbed wire. Like threading a needle. Purposefully set up.  113. They’re not on a road now but smooth concrete. Like the entry to a museum or school.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty-one, forty-two, forty-three, Boy, stop! Boy skids to a stop. They're still in the barbed-wire corridor. Boy reaches, pulling Girl three steps further, into a cor where the wire dogs right-- And a large stone PLACARD is set into the walkway. His hand touches and pulls Girl to face their right. As they run this final corridor, they count together. REVEALING the text on the placard as Boy and Girl run tow a set of double doors thirty paces ahead--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Running. Lost. Eyes squeezed shut. Bleeding from cuts. Favoring one leg. The monsters thunder behind her like a herd of buffalo. Then-- the inevitable. Malorie trips. Takes a hard spill on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PRESSING IN ON MALORIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: The earth trembles around her. Shadows of misshapen feet pass by, shark-swift. All the while she keeps her eyes shut. Shaking in terror.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SCHOOL ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Boy and Girl reach the doors just as a door opens. RICK steps out to steer them in, built like a lumberjack, both eyes full of cataracts. He’s completely blind.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Children! In here! Girl rushes to the sound of his voice, lets him steer her through the doorway inside.  114. Boy reaches Rick but stops short of going in. Instead, Boy turns and shouts out toward Malorie:

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Malorie! TIGHTER ON MALORIE’S FACE Among the rasping of the creatures surrounding her. Through it, the distant voice of Boy. One of those THINGS turns her over on her back. Shadows fall over her face.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Stay. AWAY. She finds her strength again and rises. Clutching something in her fist. A knife. She raises it in threatening gesture--

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to look at you. Then she turns the knife blade on herself. Holds its tip a centimeter from her eyelid.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l make sure of it. Beat. Remaining TIGHT on Malorie, glimpsing only briefly one of those things behind her, blurred, moving unlike anything lives in this reality. Sounds of movement, around her. She presses the blade to her lid. Piercing it enough to elicit a drop of blood. The monsters all retreat. As if they somehow know, as the did in the attic: She won’t look. With that, Malorie collapses again to the ground. PULLING BACK AND UP, revealing more of the world around Malorie. The creatures always just offscreen. Their shadows from the sun dance over her body, elongated distorted beyond accurate description as they retreat.  115.

dialogues.speaker: BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Malorie! Get inside! Boy’s voice registers in Malorie’s ears. She raises her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering out through the narrow opening in the door, over Rick’s shoulder. Malorie limps the final steps of the barbed-wire corridor drawn to Rick’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just a little further, that’s it. She steps inside with Rick’s guidance, and Rick shuts the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. You’re safe now. Malorie dares to open her eyes. This is her destination. it’s not safe now, there’s no other option. She does. The school grounds are protected by high walls and overha letting in natural light. The main space is a garden-like courtyard with trees, the roof built as a chain-link cage, creating a kind of aviar More PEOPLE OF ALL AGES gather to greet them. Some of the blind, but many who are sighted. Refugees, like Malorie. Malorie takes it in and starts to weep.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Can we look now? Malorie pulls Girl and Boy close. With a wet face:

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you can look. She pulls at their blindfolds. Boy and Girl look around at all the people. And at the sk And the trees.  116. They want to look everywhere at once. Because they’ve nev seen any of it before. Rick crouches down beside them.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And what are your names?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Girl. Rick tilts his head. What? But Malorie turns the children face her.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: No. (to Boy) Your name is Tom. (to Girl) And yours is Olympia. Boy and Girl look at Malorie with wonder. Girl gasps. Their faces light up like it’s Christmas morning.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Tom? My name is Tom? Tom!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I have a name? Malorie nods. The wall she’s put up in front of her emoti begins to crack, with a hitch in her breath. She reaches out and brings them both close, into a hug. I the kind of affection they’ve craved for years. They hug back, clinging to Malorie, not wanting to break the spell When they part, Boy and Girl then run to the other CHILDR in the group and begin introducing themselves with their names, like it’s a new outfit they’re showing off. Boy remembers the budgie in the shoebox, goes to it and o the lid of the box. Inside: The budgie flutters. Looks sideways at Boy.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Go on, now. He picks it up in cupped hands, and lets it free. The little bird takes to the air, now in the safety of th outdoor aviary.  117. Rick puts a gentle hand on Malorie’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Are they both yours? Malorie finally owns it. Watching the children look wide- at the world, she smiles proudly through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: MALORIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m their mother. FADE OUT. THE END.
